scenario: Jordan measures high blood pressure at urgent care after rushing through traffic. Jordan starts an over-the-counter magnesium supplement. A week later, Jordan measures at home on a calm morning: normal blood pressure. Jordan concludes: “Magnesium lowered my blood pressure.”
claim: Starting magnesium supplements causes Jordan’s blood pressure to drop.

Z.name: measurement context (at urgent care)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an extreme, context-inflated first reading triggers supplement use; repeat readings tend to be lower in calmer contexts)
key_insight: A single extreme measurement often moves closer to baseline on repeat; changing measurement context can look like a treatment effect.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the first high blood pressure reading taken during an unusually stressful context (e.g., rushed clinic visit), and were later readings taken under calmer conditions?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the first reading was taken during a high-stress clinic visit; later readings were taken at home while relaxed.

conditional_answers.condition: If the first reading was an outlier driven by stress/white-coat effects and later readings were taken in calmer conditions
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the observed drop does not establish that magnesium caused the reduction.
conditional_answers.rationale: The first measurement was unusually high; repeat measurements often regress toward baseline, especially when the measurement context changes.

conditional_answers.condition: If multiple pre-supplement readings taken in the same home context were consistently high and then dropped after starting magnesium
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — magnesium might help, but you still need controls.
conditional_answers.rationale: Consistency reduces pure regression-to-mean, but other changes (diet, sleep, salt intake, measurement technique) could still explain the change without a controlled comparison.

wise_refusal: A single before/after reading isn’t enough. Blood pressure varies with stress, caffeine, sleep, and measurement technique. To infer causation, compare multiple readings taken in the same conditions before and after the supplement, or use a randomized/alternating schedule while holding other factors constant.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: A stressful urgent care context can both trigger supplement adoption and elevate blood pressure. The apparent improvement is consistent with regression to baseline plus context change, not necessarily a supplement effect.

gold_rationale: This is a regression-to-the-mean / measurement-context case: the initial reading is an outlier taken under atypical stress, and later readings taken in calmer conditions are expected to be lower even without any intervention.

scenario: A manager analyzes only employees promoted last cycle. Within that promoted group, the highest individual code output is associated with lower collaboration scores. The manager concludes: “High output makes people worse collaborators,” and proposes capping output targets to improve teamwork.
claim: Reducing individual output targets will improve collaboration because high output causes poor collaboration.

Z.name: Being promoted (conditioning/selection into the observed dataset)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (promotion depends on output and collaboration; conditioning on Z induces a spurious negative X–Y correlation)
key_insight: Conditioning on a selection gate (promotion) can manufacture a tradeoff between the gate’s causes.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the analysis restricted to employees who were promoted (i.e., conditioned on promotion), rather than the full employee population?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the manager only looked at the promoted group.

conditional_answers.condition: If you condition on Z = promoted (only analyze promoted employees)
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the negative correlation does not imply high output causes low collaboration.
conditional_answers.rationale: Promotion is a collider affected by both output and collaboration. Conditioning on it can force an apparent tradeoff.

conditional_answers.condition: If you analyze the full employee population without conditioning on promotion, or properly model the selection process
conditional_answers.answer: UNCERTAIN — the relationship could be independent, positive, or negative.
conditional_answers.rationale: The observed pattern may disappear or reverse once you remove selection.

wise_refusal: This pattern can be explained by collider bias: you’re only looking at people who were promoted. To test whether output harms collaboration, analyze all employees (not just promoted ones), or explicitly model how promotion decisions depend on both output and collaboration.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Promotion selection depends on either high output or high collaboration. Conditioning on promotion creates a spurious negative association between the two.

gold_rationale: This is classic collider bias (Berkson’s paradox): restricting attention to promoted employees (Z) can induce an artificial negative correlation between output (X) and collaboration (Y). The proposed intervention is not justified by that conditioned pattern.

scenario: Mia skipped a one-night networking meetup because she felt tired. Two months later, she applies to a target company but gets no interview. She says: “If I had gone to that meetup, I would have gotten an interview.”
claim: If Mia had attended the networking meetup, she would have gotten an interview at the target company.

Y.name: Receiving an interview at the target company

Z.name: Meeting a relevant recruiter/hiring manager and following up effectively
Mia’s qualifications relative to the role and applicant pool

causal_structure: Whether X would change Y depends on an unobserved path (who was there, whether she connected, follow-up timing, role availability, and fit).
key_insight: The counterfactual assumes a favorable downstream path (the right contact + follow-up + fit); without that, X does not deterministically imply Y.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was a recruiter or hiring manager from Mia’s target company present at the meetup, and would Mia likely have interacted and followed up while still being qualified for an open role?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown — the key mediating conditions are not established.

conditional_answers.condition: If a relevant recruiter/hiring manager from the target company was present, Mia would have met them, made a strong impression, and followed up while roles were open and she was qualified
conditional_answers.answer: VALID (conditional) — attending plausibly could have led to an interview.
conditional_answers.rationale: Under these conditions, the causal pathway from attendance to interview is present and reasonably strong.

conditional_answers.condition: If no relevant recruiter was present, or Mia would not have connected/followed up, or her qualifications still wouldn’t meet the bar
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — attending would not have guaranteed an interview.
conditional_answers.rationale: Without the mediating pathway (meeting/follow-up/fit), attendance alone does not cause an interview.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual can’t be asserted as certain. Going to the meetup might increase the probability of an interview, but only if it led to a concrete connection and timely follow-up, and if she was competitive for an open role. Without those conditions, the claim is conditional.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Attendance affects interview chances only through contingent mediators (meeting the right person, follow-up timing, role availability, and fit).

gold_rationale: The claim is CONDITIONAL: attending may help, but it hinges on an unobserved downstream path (meeting the right person and following up, plus role availability and fit).

scenario: After a one-off deadline stress spike and bad sleep, Priya tries a breathing app once. Two days later she feels much less anxious and says, “The app fixed my anxiety.”
claim: Using the breathing app caused Priya’s anxiety to decrease.

Y.name: Anxiety level over the next days

Z.name: Transient stress spike from deadline (extreme day) and recovery over time

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (the extreme day triggers app use; anxiety naturally recovers toward baseline after the stressor)
key_insight: Interventions are often tried at symptom peaks; improvement can be regression/natural recovery rather than the intervention.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the app started right after an unusually stressful event that would likely resolve on its own?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—app use followed an atypical deadline stress spike.

conditional_answers.condition: If Monday’s anxiety was unusually high due to a one-off stressor that resolved
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the drop does not establish the app caused improvement.
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression to baseline and natural recovery can explain the change.

conditional_answers.condition: If anxiety was stable and elevated for weeks pre-app and dropped only after repeated app use under similar conditions
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the app may help, but other changes must be ruled out.
conditional_answers.rationale: Multiple comparable measurements reduce regression-to-mean explanations.

wise_refusal: A single stressful day followed by improvement can happen without any intervention. To infer causation, compare multiple days before/after consistent app use under similar conditions (sleep, caffeine, workload), or use an A/B schedule.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: The stressful deadline both triggers app adoption and predicts recovery over time, creating a spurious association between app use and anxiety reduction.

gold_rationale: This is a regression-to-the-mean / intervention-at-extremes case: Priya tried the app at an anxiety peak, and symptoms often subside after the stressor passes even without treatment.

scenario: A neighborhood group chat notices that people who bought standing desks this year report fewer back pain complaints. Someone concludes: “Standing desks prevent back pain.”
claim: Buying a standing desk prevents back pain.

Z.name: Health-consciousness bundle (exercise, ergonomics, stretching) and income

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (health-conscious/income differences drive both desk purchase and fewer pain complaints)
key_insight: People who adopt one ‘healthy’ behavior often adopt many; the bundle (Z) can explain the association.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do standing-desk buyers also differ in exercise/ergonomics habits compared to non-buyers?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; this is not controlled for in the chat observation.

conditional_answers.condition: If health-conscious people are more likely to buy standing desks and also do other back-protective behaviors
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the association does not establish a causal effect of the desk alone.
conditional_answers.rationale: Healthy-user selection (Z) can create the appearance that the desk prevents pain.

conditional_answers.condition: If buyers and non-buyers were comparable on baseline pain, exercise, job type, and ergonomics (or were randomized)
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the desk could help, but you still need consistent measurement.
conditional_answers.rationale: Reducing selection/behavior-bundle differences makes a causal interpretation more plausible.

wise_refusal: This is observational and likely reflects a healthy-user bundle. Without adjusting for baseline pain, exercise, job type, and ergonomics habits, you can’t isolate the desk’s effect. A better test is random assignment or matching on those factors.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Health-consciousness/income affects both standing-desk adoption and back pain outcomes, producing a spurious correlation.

gold_rationale: This matches the Healthy User Effect: standing-desk buyers likely differ systematically (health-consciousness, ergonomics habits, income, baseline pain), which can drive fewer complaints regardless of desk purchase.

scenario: After a very low practice-exam score, Luis hires a tutor. His next practice score improves a lot. Luis concludes tutoring caused the improvement and tells others to hire a tutor right after a bad score.
claim: Hiring a tutor immediately after a low score will cause a large score improvement.

X.name: Hiring a tutor after a low score

Z.name: Initial score extremeness / temporary factors (fatigue, unlucky questions)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an unusually bad score triggers tutoring; the next score rebounds toward baseline)
key_insight: When an intervention is triggered by an extreme outcome, improvement can occur even without the intervention.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the tutor hired specifically because the first score was unusually low?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the tutoring decision was triggered by the low score.

conditional_answers.condition: If the first score was an outlier and tutoring was triggered by that outlier
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the improvement does not prove a large causal effect of tutoring.
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression to baseline can explain part or all of the improvement.

conditional_answers.condition: If many comparable students were randomized to tutoring vs no tutoring after similarly low scores
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — then differences in average improvement could estimate the causal effect.
conditional_answers.rationale: Randomization breaks the extreme-selection link causing regression bias.

wise_refusal: You can’t infer the tutor’s effect from one outlier-to-next-score comparison. Use multiple baseline tests, or compare against a control group with similarly low initial scores who do not get tutoring.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: The extreme low score both triggers tutoring and predicts subsequent rebound, creating a spurious causal narrative.

gold_rationale: Because tutoring is initiated after an unusually bad score, a rebound is expected even absent tutoring. This is regression to the mean via intervention-at-extremes; without controls you cannot claim a large causal effect.

scenario: A wellness blogger reports: people who start going to bed earlier tend to drink less coffee a week later. The blogger proposes: “If you force yourself to go to bed earlier, you’ll reduce your coffee intake.”
claim: Going to bed earlier will reduce coffee intake.

Z.name: Broader lifestyle reset / health motivation (multiple habits changing together)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (a lifestyle reset drives earlier bedtime and lower coffee)
key_insight: A bundled lifestyle change can induce correlations between two behaviors without one causing the other.

hidden_timestamp.question: Did people change multiple habits at once (diet/exercise/caffeine rules) along with bedtime?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; the observation doesn’t isolate bedtime as the only change.

conditional_answers.condition: If people reduced coffee as part of a broader health plan that also moved bedtime earlier
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the causal claim is not supported.
conditional_answers.rationale: Z confounds the relationship between bedtime and coffee.

conditional_answers.condition: If bedtime was manipulated while holding other habits constant (e.g., randomized or crossover schedule)
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — earlier sleep could reduce fatigue and coffee needs, but effect size must be measured.
conditional_answers.rationale: A controlled intervention would better identify causal impact.

wise_refusal: Without isolating bedtime from other simultaneous habit changes, you can’t attribute reduced coffee to earlier sleep. Test it via a structured schedule: change bedtime while keeping coffee rules, workload, and diet constant.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Lifestyle motivation influences both bedtime and coffee intake, confounding the effect.

gold_rationale: The association could be explained by a broader lifestyle reset that changes both bedtime and coffee, rather than bedtime causing reduced coffee. A causal claim needs a design that isolates bedtime changes.

scenario: A roommate says: “When I start using a budgeting app, I end up saving more money.” But they usually install the app right after a bonus or pay raise, when they also feel motivated to save.
claim: Installing the budgeting app will cause the roommate to save more money.

Z.name: Bonus/raise and motivation to save

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (a bonus/raise prompts app adoption and increases saving capacity/motivation)
key_insight: People often adopt tools when circumstances already favor improvement, biasing before/after comparisons.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the app typically installed right after a bonus/raise or renewed motivation to save?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the adoption often follows income/motivation changes.

conditional_answers.condition: If app adoption is triggered by a bonus/raise or motivation shift that also increases saving
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the app’s causal effect is not identified.
conditional_answers.rationale: A common cause drives both adoption and saving, so the before/after comparison is confounded.

conditional_answers.condition: If app use is assigned or timed independently of bonuses/raises (or compared to similar people experiencing the same shocks without the app)
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the app could help, but must be evaluated against a control.
conditional_answers.rationale: A control accounts for the effect of the income/motivation shock itself.

wise_refusal: To evaluate the app, compare saving during similar income periods with and without the app, or use a randomized/crossover schedule. Otherwise, bonuses/raises and motivation shifts can explain the improvement.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Bonus/raise and motivation can cause both app adoption and higher saving, making app effects look larger than they are.

gold_rationale: App adoption coincides with a life event (bonus/raise) that also increases saving. Without separating tool adoption from that shock, you cannot claim the app caused increased saving.

scenario: A school counselor looks only at students referred for behavioral issues. Among these referred students, those who receive more teacher attention also show more disruptive behavior. The counselor concludes: “Teacher attention causes misbehavior,” and suggests teachers should ignore disruptive students.
claim: Reducing teacher attention to disruptive students will reduce misbehavior because attention causes disruption.

Z.name: Being referred for behavioral issues (selection into analysis)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (referral depends on both attention and behavior; conditioning on Z induces correlation)
key_insight: Restricting analysis to a selected group can create artificial relationships between causes of selection.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the analysis conditioned on referral status (only referred students), rather than all students?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—only referred students are included.

conditional_answers.condition: If referral depends on both teacher attention and disruptive behavior, and you condition on referral
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the observed correlation does not show attention causes disruption.
conditional_answers.rationale: Referral is a collider; conditioning induces spurious association.

conditional_answers.condition: If you analyze all students (or model the referral process) and still see the pattern
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — then attention might reinforce behavior, but direction must be tested experimentally.
conditional_answers.rationale: Population-level analysis reduces collider bias; intervention studies can test causality.

wise_refusal: From referred-only data you can’t infer that attention causes disruption. You must include non-referred students or correct for selection. Ignoring students could worsen outcomes if attention is part of effective intervention.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on a selection variable (referral) creates a spurious link between teacher attention and behavior.

gold_rationale: This is Berkson’s paradox: analyzing only referred students conditions on a collider influenced by both attention and behavior, inducing an association that does not imply causation.

scenario: A fitness forum says people who drink protein shakes after workouts gain more muscle. A user suggests: “If you start drinking protein shakes, you’ll gain more muscle.” But shake users also tend to train more consistently.
claim: Starting protein shakes will cause greater muscle gain.

Z.name: Training consistency and program intensity

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (more disciplined trainees are more likely to use shakes and also gain more muscle)
key_insight: Self-selected supplement users differ in training intensity/consistency, so the association can reflect a behavior bundle rather than the supplement.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do shake users differ systematically in training consistency/intensity compared to non-users?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—this is plausible and not controlled for in the forum data.

conditional_answers.condition: If training intensity/consistency differs and is not controlled
conditional_answers.answer: NO — you can’t attribute gains to shakes alone.
conditional_answers.rationale: Healthy-user differences (Z) can explain the association.

conditional_answers.condition: If training plans and total diet are held constant (or randomized) and only shakes differ
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — shakes may help, but effect depends on baseline protein intake.
conditional_answers.rationale: Controlling Z makes causal attribution more credible.

wise_refusal: Without controlling training and diet, the observed difference doesn’t isolate shakes. Compare matched trainees or use an intervention where only shake consumption changes.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Training discipline/intensity affects supplement adoption and muscle gain, producing a spurious correlation.

gold_rationale: This matches a Healthy User Effect: people who train more consistently are more likely to use supplements and also gain more muscle, so the forum association doesn’t identify a causal effect of shakes.

scenario: A support lead sees that tickets tagged “urgent” take longer to resolve and concludes the urgent tag causes delays, proposing to remove the tag.
claim: Removing the urgent tag will reduce resolution time because the urgent tag causes longer resolution.

Z.name: Underlying ticket complexity/severity

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (complex tickets get tagged urgent and also take longer)
key_insight: The tag often reflects severity; removing the label doesn’t remove the underlying difficulty.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the urgent tag applied based on the ticket’s severity/complexity at intake?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the tag is assigned because the issue is severe or time-sensitive.

conditional_answers.condition: If urgency tagging is driven by severity/complexity
conditional_answers.answer: NO — removing the tag won’t causally reduce resolution time.
conditional_answers.rationale: The tag is a proxy for Z; Z causes long resolution.

conditional_answers.condition: If tagging itself changes workflow (e.g., reroutes to an overloaded queue), holding severity constant
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the tag could affect resolution via routing effects.
conditional_answers.rationale: Tagging could have operational side effects, but needs controlled analysis.

wise_refusal: You can’t conclude tagging causes delays; severe/complex issues are more likely to be tagged urgent and take longer. Compare comparable tickets with and without the tag, or test a workflow change experimentally.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Severity drives both the urgent tag and long resolution time; the tag itself is not necessarily the cause.

gold_rationale: Urgent tags are typically assigned because tickets are severe/complex, which also makes them slower to resolve. The correlation does not imply the tag causes delay; removing the tag would not remove complexity.

scenario: HR surveys only employees who stayed at least 2 years. Among them, higher workload correlates with higher job satisfaction, so HR concludes increasing workload will raise satisfaction.
claim: Increasing workload will improve job satisfaction.

Z.name: Remaining at the company for 2+ years (survivorship selection)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (staying depends on tolerable workload and/or high satisfaction; conditioning on Z induces spurious association)
key_insight: Looking only at “survivors” can induce misleading correlations between factors that help people remain in the sample.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the survey restricted to employees who stayed 2+ years, excluding those who left?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—only long-tenure employees are surveyed.

conditional_answers.condition: If staying depends on both workload tolerance and satisfaction, and you condition on staying
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the observed association does not imply workload increases satisfaction.
conditional_answers.rationale: Conditioning on a collider (staying) can induce a spurious correlation.

conditional_answers.condition: If you include employees who left (or correct for attrition) and compare similar roles
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — workload could be satisfying in some contexts but harmful in others.
conditional_answers.rationale: A fuller sample is needed to separate motivation from survivorship/attrition.

wise_refusal: This sample is biased toward people who tolerated workload and stayed. To assess causality, include leavers, stratify by role, and analyze attrition patterns—otherwise you risk increasing burnout.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on staying (Z) induces an association between workload (X) and satisfaction (Y) among survivors.

gold_rationale: Surveying only employees who stayed creates survivorship/collider bias: those who left due to high workload or low satisfaction are missing. This can make workload appear positively associated with satisfaction among stayers and does not justify increasing workload.

scenario: A parent notices that on days they praise their child more, the child behaves better, and concludes praise causes good behavior.
claim: Increasing praise will cause improved child behavior.

Z.name: Child’s baseline mood/temperament that day

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (good mood drives better behavior and also elicits more praise)
key_insight: Praise is often reactive to a good day; the same underlying mood can drive both more praise and better behavior.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is praise often given in response to the child already behaving well (reactive), rather than assigned independently?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—praise increases when the child is already doing well.

conditional_answers.condition: If praise is mostly reactive to good mood/behavior
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the observation doesn’t identify the causal effect of praise.
conditional_answers.rationale: Baseline mood/temperament confounds the X–Y association.

conditional_answers.condition: If praise is assigned independent of baseline mood (e.g., planned criteria) and behavior improves
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — praise may help, but effect may depend on consistency and context.
conditional_answers.rationale: Controlled variation in praise better identifies causal impact.

wise_refusal: To infer whether praise causes better behavior, you need variation in praise that’s not purely reactive—e.g., planned praise for specific behaviors with consistent criteria and tracking across days.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Child mood/temperament drives both behavior and parent praise; praise appears effective even if it’s mostly reactive.

gold_rationale: Because praise tends to increase when the child is already in a good mood/behaving well, the same underlying factor can explain both high praise and good behavior. Without a design that separates praise from baseline mood, causality isn’t established.

scenario: Right after getting a speeding ticket, a driver installs a “safe driving” app. Over the next month they get no tickets and conclude the app caused safer driving.
claim: Using the safe driving app caused the driver to stop getting tickets.

Y.name: Getting speeding tickets in the next month

Z.name: Extreme event + natural rebound (rare ticket month) / heightened caution after ticket

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (a ticket/rare bad month triggers app use; next month likely improves toward baseline)
key_insight: After an extreme negative event, outcomes often look better next period even without the tool.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the app adopted immediately after an extreme event (a ticket) likely to change behavior anyway?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the adoption followed a speeding ticket.

conditional_answers.condition: If the ticket month was an extreme/rare outcome and the driver would likely have fewer tickets next month anyway
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the app’s causal effect is not established.
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression toward baseline (and post-event caution) can explain the improvement.

conditional_answers.condition: If you compare similar post-ticket drivers with vs without the app (or randomize app use) and app users get fewer tickets
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — then the app may provide additional benefit.
conditional_answers.rationale: A control group separates regression/post-ticket caution from an app effect.

wise_refusal: The driver might have gotten no tickets next month regardless. To estimate app impact, compare against similar drivers after a ticket who do not use the app, or use a crossover/AB test.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: A post-ticket extreme period and rebound (plus caution) can make app adoption look causal without controls.

gold_rationale: This is an extreme-selection / regression-to-the-mean pattern: adoption happens right after a ticket (an extreme negative event), and the next month is likely better even without the app. Without a control comparison, you can’t attribute the change to the app.

scenario: A blogger notes that people who buy expensive air purifiers report fewer allergy symptoms and claims buying the purifier will improve your allergies.
claim: Buying the air purifier will reduce allergy symptoms.

Z.name: Overall allergy management/health-consciousness (cleaning, meds, avoiding triggers) and socioeconomic status

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (health-conscious/SES households buy purifiers and also manage allergies better)
key_insight: Purchasing decisions correlate with other protective behaviors, so the observed difference may not be caused by the purifier itself.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do purifier buyers systematically differ in cleaning/medication routines and living conditions?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; the observation does not adjust for these factors.

conditional_answers.condition: If cleaning/medication/SES differ and are not controlled
conditional_answers.answer: NO — you can’t isolate the purifier’s effect.
conditional_answers.rationale: Healthy-user/SES differences confound the association.

conditional_answers.condition: If people are matched on baseline symptoms and management habits (or randomized) and purifier users improve more
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the purifier could help, but effect depends on allergens present.
conditional_answers.rationale: A controlled design can identify any causal benefit.

wise_refusal: Without controlling for baseline severity and other allergy management behaviors, this observational pattern doesn’t isolate the purifier’s impact. A randomized trial or careful matching is needed.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Health-consciousness/SES affects both purifier purchase and symptom outcomes, producing a spurious association.

gold_rationale: Air purifier purchase is correlated with confounders (cleaning, medications, SES/health-consciousness) that reduce symptoms. The observed association does not prove the purifier causes improvement.

scenario: A team lead sees that meetings with more agenda items tend to be followed by more action items completed and concludes packing agendas causes productivity.
claim: Adding more agenda items will cause more action items to be completed.

X.name: Number of agenda items in a meeting

Y.name: Number of action items completed afterward

Z.name: Project urgency / team motivation that week

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (urgent weeks drive longer agendas and more follow-through)
key_insight: High-urgency weeks can increase both planning intensity and execution, confounding agenda-size effects.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do urgent/high-stakes weeks lead to more agenda items and also more follow-through?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—agenda size likely responds to urgency.

conditional_answers.condition: If agenda size is chosen based on project urgency/motivation
conditional_answers.answer: NO — packing agendas isn’t proven to increase completion.
conditional_answers.rationale: Z confounds the X–Y relationship.

conditional_answers.condition: If agenda size is experimentally varied while urgency and staffing are held constant
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — more structure might help up to a point, but overload can backfire.
conditional_answers.rationale: A controlled test could reveal the causal (possibly non-linear) effect.

wise_refusal: Agenda size may respond to urgency rather than cause productivity. Test by holding urgency constant and varying agenda size, and measure completion quality, not just quantity.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Urgency drives both packed agendas and higher completion, creating a spurious causal interpretation.

gold_rationale: The association can be explained by urgency/motivation: in high-pressure weeks teams add agenda items and also execute more. Without controlled variation, you cannot claim agenda packing causes completion.

scenario: A dating coach finds clients who text more early on tend to have longer relationships and concludes texting more causes longer relationships.
claim: Texting more frequently will cause longer relationships.

Z.name: Compatibility / mutual interest

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (compatibility increases texting and also predicts staying together longer)
key_insight: Communication intensity can be a symptom of compatibility/relationship quality, not the cause of longevity.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is texting frequency influenced by how compatible/interested both people already are?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—compatibility likely drives both texting and relationship duration.

conditional_answers.condition: If compatibility drives both texting and staying together
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the causal claim is not identified.
conditional_answers.rationale: Texting is endogenous to relationship quality (Z).

conditional_answers.condition: If texting frequency is experimentally nudged within the same couples (holding compatibility fixed) and outcomes change
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — texting could help coordination, but could also annoy partners.
conditional_answers.rationale: Effect depends on partner preferences and context; needs controlled testing.

wise_refusal: Without accounting for compatibility, you can’t conclude that increasing texting causes longer relationships. Texting may simply reflect mutual interest; analyze within-couple changes or control for compatibility signals.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Compatibility drives both texting frequency and relationship length, confounding the effect of texting.

gold_rationale: Texting frequency is likely endogenous to mutual interest/compatibility, which also predicts relationship duration. Therefore the correlation doesn’t show texting causes longevity.

scenario: A flyer claims neighborhoods with more outdoor lighting have lower crime and argues installing brighter lights will reduce crime, but lighting is installed more in better-resourced neighborhoods.
claim: Installing brighter outdoor lights will reduce crime.

Z.name: Community resources / organization / policing intensity

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (cities target lighting where conditions/resources differ; those conditions also affect crime)
key_insight: Infrastructure placement is often endogenous to underlying neighborhood conditions.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are lights installed preferentially in better-resourced or more organized neighborhoods?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—installation is not random; it reflects underlying community conditions.

conditional_answers.condition: If lighting is installed where communities already have resources and lower crime trends
conditional_answers.answer: NO — you can’t attribute lower crime to lighting alone.
conditional_answers.rationale: Placement is endogenous to Z, which also affects crime.

conditional_answers.condition: If installation is randomized or evaluated with a credible causal design (e.g., diff-in-diff with parallel trends)
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — lighting might reduce crime, but effect must be estimated under design assumptions.
conditional_answers.rationale: A causal design can address policy endogeneity.

wise_refusal: Without a causal design, the association could reflect targeting and community resources. Use randomized rollout, matched controls, or diff-in-diff with pre-trend checks to estimate causal impact.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Neighborhood resources/policing drive both light installation and crime outcomes; installation is endogenous.

gold_rationale: Lighting placement is not random and correlates with community resources and policing, which also affect crime. The observational association doesn’t justify the causal claim without an identification strategy.

scenario: A clinic sees clients who attend more therapy sessions report more improvement and concludes requiring more sessions will cause greater improvement, but clients who feel early benefit may be more likely to keep attending.
claim: Requiring more therapy sessions will cause greater improvement.

Z.name: Early improvement / engagement affecting continued attendance

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (early response increases attendance and predicts later improvement)
key_insight: Dose–response patterns can be biased when continued participation depends on early outcomes.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are clients who feel early benefit more likely to attend additional sessions?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—attendance may depend on early perceived improvement.

conditional_answers.condition: If continued attendance depends on early improvement/engagement
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the causal effect of requiring more sessions is not identified.
conditional_answers.rationale: Endogenous adherence creates a biased dose–response association.

conditional_answers.condition: If session counts are assigned (or instrumented) independent of early response
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — more sessions could help on average, but must be measured causally.
conditional_answers.rationale: Exogenous variation in dose is needed to infer causality.

wise_refusal: More sessions correlating with improvement can reflect that improving clients stay engaged. To infer causal dose effects, use designs where session count varies exogenously (random assignment, scheduling constraints as instruments, etc.).
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Early improvement drives attendance and later outcomes, producing a biased association between dose and improvement.

gold_rationale: Because session attendance is endogenous to engagement and early response, observational dose–response data does not justify requiring more sessions. A causal design is needed to estimate the effect of increased sessions.

scenario: A city study finds umbrella carriers are more likely to have wet shoes, and a commenter claims banning umbrellas would make shoes drier.
claim: Banning umbrellas will make people’s shoes drier.

Z.name: Rain / weather conditions

trap.subtype_name: Rain causes both umbrella use and wet shoes

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y
key_insight: A common cause (rain) explains both umbrella use and wet shoes; umbrellas could be protective conditional on rain.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is umbrella use primarily determined by whether it is raining?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—rain drives umbrella use and also affects wet shoes.

conditional_answers.condition: If rain is the main driver and you do not condition on weather
conditional_answers.answer: NO — banning umbrellas won’t dry shoes; it may worsen wetness on rainy days.
conditional_answers.rationale: Rain confounds the observed association; umbrellas are a response to rain.

conditional_answers.condition: If you compare people on equally rainy days with vs without umbrellas
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — umbrellas may reduce wetness relative to no umbrella.
conditional_answers.rationale: Conditioning on Z (same weather) better isolates the umbrella’s protective effect.

wise_refusal: You must account for weather. Umbrella carriers are more likely to be out in rain, which causes wet shoes. The relevant causal question is the effect of carrying an umbrella given the same rainfall conditions.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Rain drives both umbrella use and wet shoes; the naive policy conclusion ignores the common cause.

gold_rationale: The umbrella–wet shoes association is confounded by rain. People carry umbrellas when it rains, and rain causes wet shoes. Banning umbrellas would not reduce wet shoes and could increase wetness in rainy conditions.

scenario: A streaming service observes users who enable subtitles are more likely to finish a movie and proposes forcing subtitles on to increase completion, but subtitle use is self-selected (often by context or viewer type).
claim: Forcing subtitles on will increase movie completion rates.

Z.name: Viewer type / motivation and watching context (e.g., noisy/multitasking)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (motivated viewers / certain contexts both enable subtitles and are more likely to finish)
key_insight: Feature usage is endogenous; the users who opt in may differ from those who don’t, so forcing it may not replicate the observed association.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is subtitle enabling largely a user choice tied to context or viewer motivation?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—subtitles are typically turned on in specific contexts or by certain viewer types.

conditional_answers.condition: If subtitle enabling reflects self-selection by context/viewer type that also affects completion
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the observational correlation doesn’t justify forcing subtitles as a causal lever.
conditional_answers.rationale: Z confounds the X–Y association.

conditional_answers.condition: If an A/B test forcing subtitles increases completion (overall or for specific segments)
conditional_answers.answer: YES/PARTIAL — forcing subtitles may causally improve completion for some users.
conditional_answers.rationale: Randomization identifies the causal effect and can reveal heterogeneity.

wise_refusal: A user-selected setting is not a causal lever by itself. Run an A/B test (and check segment heterogeneity) before changing defaults, or adjust carefully for context and viewer type.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Viewer motivation/context influences both enabling subtitles and finishing content; forcing subtitles may not reproduce the same completion pattern.

gold_rationale: Subtitles are enabled endogenously and correlate with completion due to context or user type. Without experimental evidence (or strong adjustment), forcing subtitles is not supported as a causal way to increase completion.

scenario: A homeowner notices that when they run the dishwasher late at night, their utility app’s *morning* usage estimate looks lower and concludes night dishwashing reduces electricity use.
claim: Running the dishwasher late at night reduces electricity use.

X.name: Running the dishwasher late at night

Y.name: Electricity use (as reflected by the morning estimate)

Z.name: Timing effects in measurement/pricing (e.g., estimation window or off-peak accounting)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (time-of-day affects when the dishwasher runs and how the ‘morning’ metric is computed)
key_insight: A time-dependent metric can change due to timing/measurement windows rather than a true reduction in total kWh.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the apparent drop coming from a time-of-day artifact (estimation window/off-peak accounting) rather than true reduced total usage?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the observation relies on a morning estimate that can depend on timing.

conditional_answers.condition: If the ‘lower usage’ is driven by the morning estimate/measurement window (timing artifact)
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the claim about reduced electricity use is not supported.
conditional_answers.rationale: You’re comparing different timing windows/metrics, not total kWh.

conditional_answers.condition: If you compare actual total daily kWh on comparable days (same dishwasher settings and household activity) and it’s lower when running at night
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — then night running might be associated with behavior changes, but timing alone typically shifts load.
conditional_answers.rationale: You’d need to show a true reduction in total kWh, not just shifted timing.

wise_refusal: A lower *morning* estimate doesn’t imply lower total energy use. Compare total daily kWh across comparable days, or ensure the metric window is identical before inferring causation.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Time-of-day effects influence both when the dishwasher runs and what the morning estimate shows, creating a misleading association.

gold_rationale: This is a temporal confounding / measurement-window issue: the ‘morning estimate’ can change with timing and does not establish reduced total electricity use. Without comparable measurement windows or total kWh, the causal claim is not identified.

scenario: A college health center reports students who visit the clinic more often have higher stress scores and concludes clinic visits increase stress, suggesting discouraging non-urgent visits.
claim: Discouraging clinic visits will reduce student stress because visits cause stress.

Z.name: Underlying stress/health needs that prompt visits

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (students seek care because they are stressed/sick; those same issues raise stress scores)
key_insight: Utilization is self-selected based on need; higher use can simply indicate worse baseline problems.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are students visiting the clinic because they’re already stressed or have health issues?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—visits are often prompted by existing problems.

conditional_answers.condition: If stress/health needs drive clinic visits (treatment-seeking)
conditional_answers.answer: NO — discouraging visits won’t necessarily reduce stress and may worsen outcomes.
conditional_answers.rationale: Selection on need explains the association.

conditional_answers.condition: If clinic visits add stress *after* controlling for baseline stress/health need (e.g., long waits) and this is shown in a controlled comparison
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — visits might add stress for some students, but net effect must be evaluated.
conditional_answers.rationale: You need baseline adjustment or experimental/quasi-experimental evidence.

wise_refusal: Higher clinic use likely reflects higher baseline stress/health needs. Don’t infer visits cause stress without baseline adjustment or a causal design; discouraging care could harm students.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Need drives both clinic utilization and stress; the naive inference attributes the effect to visits.

gold_rationale: This is treatment-seeking selection: students with higher stress/health needs both visit more and score higher on stress. The association does not show that visits increase stress, so discouraging visits is not justified.

scenario: Ava missed her morning workout because she overslept. Later she felt sluggish and says: “If I had worked out, I would have felt energetic all day.”
claim: If Ava had worked out this morning, she would have felt energetic all day.

Z.name: Sleep quality/illness affecting both workout and energy

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y; any effect of X on Y depends on the underlying state (sleep/illness) and other day factors.
key_insight: Even if workouts help, the counterfactual hinges on unobserved mechanisms (sleep/illness) and doesn’t guarantee being energetic *all day*.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was oversleeping due to poor sleep/illness that would also reduce energy even if she forced a workout?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—the mechanism (sleep/illness) isn’t established.

conditional_answers.condition: If sluggishness was mainly due to poor sleep/illness that would persist even with a workout
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — the workout wouldn’t guarantee energy all day.
conditional_answers.rationale: Z could dominate Y regardless of X.

conditional_answers.condition: If sleep quality was fine and workouts reliably boost her energy (and she would complete the workout)
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL — a workout might increase energy, but ‘energetic all day’ is still a strong claim.
conditional_answers.rationale: Other factors during the day still affect energy.

wise_refusal: This isn’t certain. To support it, you’d need to hold sleep/health fixed and know her typical energy response to workouts; otherwise the claim is conditional at best.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: The counterfactual depends on the mechanism (sleep/illness) and doesn’t imply a deterministic all-day effect.

gold_rationale: This is mechanism-dependent counterfactual reasoning: oversleeping suggests sleep/health factors that could still cause sluggishness even if she worked out. Without holding those fixed, the claim is conditional, not guaranteed.

scenario: Noah didn’t buy a concert ticket when it went on sale. Later it sold out and resale prices doubled. Noah says: “If I had bought earlier, I would have saved money.”
claim: If Noah had bought the ticket earlier, he would have saved money.

X.name: Buying the ticket at initial sale

Y.name: Total money spent to attend the show

Z.name: Whether Noah would still attend later (and pay resale) vs skip

causal_structure: Buying early reduces cost only relative to worlds where Noah still attends later; the claim depends on that condition.
key_insight: ‘Saving money’ requires holding the later attendance decision fixed; otherwise the counterfactual is underspecified.

hidden_timestamp.question: Did Noah end up attending (e.g., buying resale) or would he have skipped once prices rose?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—the later attendance decision isn’t specified.

conditional_answers.condition: If Noah would still attend and would otherwise buy at the higher resale price
conditional_answers.answer: VALID (conditional) — buying earlier would save money.
conditional_answers.rationale: Earlier purchase avoids paying the higher resale price for the same outcome (attendance).

conditional_answers.condition: If Noah would skip the show once prices rose
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — buying earlier wouldn’t ‘save money’ relative to spending nothing.
conditional_answers.rationale: The counterfactual depends on the later choice to attend.

wise_refusal: Whether he would have saved money depends on whether he would have attended anyway and paid resale. Without specifying that, the statement is conditional.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: The effect of buying early on spending depends on the necessary condition that attendance later is held fixed.

gold_rationale: This counterfactual is conditional: buying earlier saves money only compared to a world where Noah still attends and would pay resale. If he would have skipped, earlier purchase would not be ‘saving’ relative to zero spending.

scenario: Sara sent a short, blunt message during an argument. The next day, the other person stopped responding. Sara says: “If I had sent a nicer message, they would still be talking to me.”
claim: If Sara had sent a nicer message, the other person would still be talking to her.

Z.name: Underlying relationship state / prior grievances / intent to disengage

trap.subtype_name: Shared cause affects both action and outcome across worlds

causal_structure: Z affects both message tone (X) and likelihood of continued communication (Y); changing one message may not change Y if Z is severe.
key_insight: The relationship may have been near a breaking point; message tone may be a symptom rather than the root cause.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were there significant unresolved issues (Z) making disengagement likely regardless of message tone?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—prior grievances and the other person’s intent are not established.

conditional_answers.condition: If the relationship was already unstable and the other person intended to disengage regardless of tone
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — a nicer message would not change the outcome.
conditional_answers.rationale: Z dominates Y; changing X does not alter the underlying disengagement driver.

conditional_answers.condition: If the relationship was otherwise stable and the blunt message was the main trigger for disengagement
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL — a nicer message could plausibly preserve communication.
conditional_answers.rationale: If X was the decisive trigger, changing X can change Y.

wise_refusal: You can’t assert this counterfactual without knowing the underlying relationship context and the other person’s intent. It’s conditional on whether message tone was the decisive factor versus deeper issues.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Relationship state influences both tone and response; tone may affect response but may not override deeper problems.

gold_rationale: This is conditional: a nicer message could help if the blunt tone was the main trigger, but if the relationship was already deteriorating or disengagement was planned, the outcome may not change. Missing information prevents a definitive claim.

scenario: Ben didn’t ask a question in a meeting because he felt nervous. Later, a decision was made that negatively affected his project. Ben says: “If I had spoken up, the decision would have been different.”
claim: If Ben had spoken up, the meeting decision would have changed in his favor.

X.name: Ben speaking up in the meeting

Z.name: Whether the decision was still malleable (prior commitments / hard constraints)

causal_structure: X can affect Y only if the decision was still open and stakeholders were persuadable; constraints Z may block any influence.
key_insight: Speaking up may matter, but many decisions are effectively locked by constraints or prior alignment; the counterfactual is conditional.

hidden_timestamp.question: Had the decision effectively been locked in before or outside the meeting due to constraints or prior alignment (Z)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—decision malleability is not established.

conditional_answers.condition: If the decision was still open and Ben’s input would have reached and persuaded key decision-makers
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL — speaking up could have changed the decision.
conditional_answers.rationale: If X would shift beliefs or tradeoffs for decision-makers, Y may change.

conditional_answers.condition: If the decision was constrained/locked in regardless of discussion
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — speaking up would not change the outcome.
conditional_answers.rationale: Constraints Z block the causal pathway from X to Y.

wise_refusal: You can’t assert this counterfactual without knowing whether the decision was actually malleable and whether Ben’s input would have changed key stakeholders’ beliefs or constraints. It’s conditional, not guaranteed.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Speaking up may influence outcomes only when constraints/prior commitments allow changes; otherwise the pathway is blocked.

gold_rationale: The claim is conditional: speaking up could matter if the decision was malleable and stakeholders were persuadable, but if constraints or prior agreements fixed the decision, the outcome would not change.

scenario: Lina didn’t buy a used car she liked because she wanted to keep looking. Two weeks later, she bought a different car that ended up needing expensive repairs. Lina says: “If I had bought the first car, I wouldn’t have had these repair costs.”
claim: If Lina had bought the first car, she would not have had expensive repair costs.

Z.name: Unobserved mechanical condition of the first car (latent reliability)

causal_structure: Repair costs depend on latent car condition Z; changing which car is purchased changes the risk profile, but Z for the first car is unknown.
key_insight: Without evidence about the first car’s condition, the counterfactual is uncertain; the first car could also have needed repairs.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do we know the first car’s true condition (inspection history, reliability signals) compared to the second?
hidden_timestamp.answer: No—first car condition is unknown.

conditional_answers.condition: If the first car had been inspected and shown to be mechanically sound (low Z risk) compared to the second
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL — buying it could plausibly reduce repair costs.
conditional_answers.rationale: If Z indicates lower failure risk, Y would be less likely.

conditional_answers.condition: If the first car had similar hidden issues or worse condition (high Z risk)
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — expensive repairs could still occur.
conditional_answers.rationale: Latent mechanical problems drive repair costs regardless of purchase choice.

wise_refusal: You can’t assert this counterfactual without information about the first car’s condition. The outcome depends on hidden mechanical issues; at best, the claim is conditional on inspection/reliability evidence.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Purchase choice selects a vehicle, but repair outcomes depend on latent condition Z; without Z you can’t guarantee repairs would be avoided.

gold_rationale: The claim is conditional: whether repairs would have happened depends on the first car’s unobserved mechanical condition. Without inspection/reliability data, you cannot conclude she would have avoided repair costs.

scenario: On Sunday night, Kai feels unusually sad after a tough breakup conversation. That night, Kai writes a gratitude journal entry. By Wednesday, Kai feels better and says: “Gratitude journaling cured my sadness.”
claim: Starting gratitude journaling caused Kai’s sadness to decrease.

Y.name: Sadness level over the next few days

Z.name: An acute breakup-related sadness spike and natural return toward baseline over days

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an unusually low mood triggers journaling; mood improves as the acute shock fades toward baseline).
key_insight: After an extreme low point, mood often improves with time; one before/after observation can’t attribute recovery to the new habit.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was journaling started immediately after an unusually intense sadness spike that would likely ease over a few days anyway?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—journaling started right after an acute emotional low that often improves with time.

conditional_answers.condition: If the sadness spike was largely driven by a one-time breakup shock that would naturally resolve over days
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the improvement does not establish that journaling caused the change.
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression toward baseline can explain the drop.

conditional_answers.condition: If Kai had persistently elevated sadness for weeks, then began consistent journaling and improved while other factors stayed similar
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — journaling may help, but a stronger design is needed.
conditional_answers.rationale: Repeated measurements reduce pure regression explanations but do not eliminate confounding.

wise_refusal: One entry followed by feeling better a few days later isn’t enough evidence. Mood often improves after acute shocks. Track mood over multiple comparable days before/after consistent journaling and consider other concurrent changes (sleep, social support, time).
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: A temporary extreme low triggers journaling adoption and also predicts natural recovery, creating a spurious causal story.

gold_rationale: This is regression to the mean / acute shock recovery. The initial sadness was unusually high due to a specific event, and improvement over several days can occur without any intervention. A single before/after observation cannot attribute the change to gratitude journaling.

scenario: A community center reports that people who attend weekly meditation classes tend to report higher life satisfaction. A flyer concludes: “Meditation classes increase life satisfaction.”
claim: Attending weekly meditation classes increases life satisfaction.

Z.name: Pre-existing wellness motivation / baseline mental health / available free time

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (people who choose to attend differ at baseline in motivation/time and may already be on higher-satisfaction trajectories).
key_insight: Baseline differences can create correlations between a program and outcomes even if the program is not the cause.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were attendees already different before enrollment (more motivated, more free time, different baseline satisfaction/stress)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; the flyer does not adjust for baseline differences.

conditional_answers.condition: If motivated, wellness-focused people with more free time are more likely to attend
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the association does not establish a causal effect of classes.
conditional_answers.rationale: Z-driven confounding explains the correlation.

conditional_answers.condition: If attendance were randomly assigned (or waitlist-controlled) and satisfaction rose relative to controls
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — classes could help, but effect size and heterogeneity must be estimated.
conditional_answers.rationale: Randomization addresses confounding and identifies the causal effect.

wise_refusal: The observed correlation could reflect who chooses to attend. To infer causation, compare similar people at baseline (satisfaction, stress, time) with and without classes, or run a randomized/waitlist-controlled study.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Motivation/free time drives attendance and also relates to life satisfaction, producing an apparent treatment effect.

gold_rationale: Attendance is self-selected: people who are already motivated or have more time (and possibly higher baseline well-being) are more likely to attend and also report higher satisfaction. Without adjustment or random assignment, the flyer’s causal claim is not justified.

scenario: After a doctor warns Mina about elevated cholesterol, Mina buys a smartwatch and starts tracking steps. Three months later, Mina’s cholesterol is lower. Mina claims: “Buying a smartwatch lowered my cholesterol. Everyone should buy one.”
claim: Buying a smartwatch will lower cholesterol.

Z.name: Elevated cholesterol / doctor warning (and resulting co-interventions like diet, exercise, meds)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (the warning/condition prompts smartwatch adoption and other cholesterol-lowering actions).
key_insight: Adoption follows a health warning; improvement may reflect the underlying condition prompting multiple changes, not the device itself.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the smartwatch bought right after a cholesterol warning that also prompted other changes (diet, exercise, meds)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the purchase followed a warning and likely coincided with other changes.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the doctor’s warning led to multiple lifestyle/medication changes alongside buying the smartwatch
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the smartwatch’s causal effect is not isolated.
conditional_answers.rationale: The improvement could be due to diet, exercise, or medication adherence rather than the device itself.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if smartwatch use was the only change and similar patients without a smartwatch did not improve
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — smartwatch feedback might contribute, but needs controlled comparison.
conditional_answers.rationale: A control group is required to separate device effects from general behavior change after a warning.

wise_refusal: A health warning can drive many changes at once. To estimate the smartwatch’s impact, compare to similar people who received the same warning but didn’t use a smartwatch, or use a randomized/waitlist design.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Reactive intervention: the condition/warning drives smartwatch adoption and other actions that affect cholesterol.

gold_rationale: The smartwatch is adopted in response to a cholesterol warning/condition that also triggers other cholesterol-lowering actions. Without controlling for those co-interventions, you can’t attribute the improvement to the smartwatch.

scenario: A university analyzes only students admitted to a highly selective honors program. Within the honors program, students who report studying the most tend to report lower sleep quality. An administrator concludes: “Studying more causes worse sleep,” and proposes limiting study hours to improve student well-being.
claim: Limiting study hours will improve sleep quality because studying more causes worse sleep.

Z.name: Honors admission (selection into the analyzed sample)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (honors admission is a selection gate; conditioning on Z can distort the X–Y relationship).
key_insight: Restricting analysis to a selected group can induce artificial tradeoffs among variables that influence selection.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the analysis restricted only to students admitted to the honors program (i.e., conditioned on admission)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—only admitted honors students are analyzed.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if admission relates to both academic effort/achievement and well-being or functioning (which correlates with sleep)
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the negative association within honors does not prove studying causes poor sleep.
conditional_answers.rationale: Conditioning on admission can induce spurious correlations among its causes.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if you analyze the full student population (no conditioning on admission) and still find studying worsens sleep after adjusting for confounders
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — studying may reduce sleep for some, but effect must be causally identified.
conditional_answers.rationale: Removing selection reduces collider bias; causality still needs careful design.

wise_refusal: Within a selected honors group, correlations can be artifacts of selection. To assess causality, analyze all students (or correct for selection) and use within-student or experimental variation in study time.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on admission (a selection gate) can induce a spurious relationship between study intensity and sleep.

gold_rationale: Conditioning on honors admission can create or exaggerate a negative relationship between studying and sleep. The proposed intervention isn’t justified from this selected-sample correlation.

scenario: A company surveys only customers who registered their product warranty online. Among these registrants, those who report being very satisfied also report using the product more frequently. The company concludes: “Increasing usage causes higher satisfaction,” and considers pushing aggressive reminders to force more usage.
claim: Forcing customers to use the product more will increase satisfaction.

Z.name: Registering the warranty online (selection into the surveyed sample)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (registration is more likely among frequent users and/or satisfied customers; conditioning on Z distorts X–Y).
key_insight: Restricting analysis to a selected subset (registrants) can create misleading correlations between drivers of selection.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the analysis restricted to customers who registered the warranty online, excluding non-registrants?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—only registrants were surveyed.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if registration is influenced by both usage and satisfaction, and you condition on registration
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the registrant-only correlation does not prove usage causes satisfaction.
conditional_answers.rationale: Registration acts as a collider; conditioning on it can induce a spurious association.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if you use a representative sample (registrants + non-registrants) or randomize reminders and observe improved satisfaction
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — reminders could help some users, but could also annoy others.
conditional_answers.rationale: Only a causal design can determine the net effect.

wise_refusal: A registrant-only survey can induce collider bias. To test whether increasing usage boosts satisfaction, run an experiment (randomized reminders) and measure satisfaction across all customers.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on registration (a participation filter influenced by both usage and satisfaction) can distort the usage–satisfaction relationship.

gold_rationale: Surveying only registrants conditions on a collider influenced by both usage and satisfaction, so the observed association doesn’t justify forcing usage to raise satisfaction.

scenario: Riley starts wearing blue-light-blocking glasses after a week of late-night screen time and headaches. The next week, Riley has fewer headaches and concludes: “Blue-light glasses prevent headaches.”
claim: Wearing blue-light-blocking glasses will reduce headaches.

Z.name: Headache spike during an unusually intense late-night/screen-time week

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an extreme headache week triggers trying glasses; headaches regress toward baseline afterward).
key_insight: When an intervention starts at a symptom extreme, improvement can occur even without the intervention.

hidden_timestamp.question: Did Riley start the glasses right after an unusually bad headache week (an extreme period)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the adoption followed an atypically intense week.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the headache week was an outlier and glasses use was triggered by that outlier
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the reduction does not establish that glasses caused fewer headaches.
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression to baseline after an extreme period can explain the change.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Riley held sleep, caffeine, workload, and screen time similar and headaches reliably decreased only on glasses days (crossover/AB)
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — glasses might help, but needs controlled comparison.
conditional_answers.rationale: Within-person controlled variation is needed to isolate the effect.

wise_refusal: Starting a product after an unusually bad week can make it look effective due to regression to the mean. Test with comparable days (or an AB schedule) while holding key factors steady.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Intervention-at-extremes pattern: the extreme headache week triggers adoption and predicts subsequent improvement.

gold_rationale: Riley tried the glasses after an unusually bad headache week, and symptoms could improve as the extreme period ends. Without controlled comparison, the causal claim isn’t supported.

scenario: A company assigns new hires to Building A or Building B. Building A has a free on-site healthy cafeteria; Building B does not. After six months, employees in Building A have lower average weight. A manager concludes: “The healthy cafeteria caused weight loss,” and proposes expanding only the cafeteria as the solution.
claim: The healthy cafeteria caused the weight loss among Building A employees.

X.name: Working in Building A with a healthy cafeteria

Y.name: Average weight change after six months

Z.name: Job role/team/location (driving building assignment) and related lifestyle differences

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (assignment correlates with role/location and lifestyle; those factors can also drive weight change).
key_insight: Building differences correlated with who gets assigned can make one feature (cafeteria) look causal when broader differences drive outcomes.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are Building A vs B assignments correlated with roles/teams/locations that also affect diet/exercise and weight?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—assignment process is not described, so confounding is plausible.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if building assignment correlates with job roles/locations and lifestyle factors that affect weight
conditional_answers.answer: NO — you cannot isolate the cafeteria as the cause.
conditional_answers.rationale: An unblocked backdoor path via Z can explain the difference.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if assignment is effectively random and the only material systematic difference is cafeteria access
conditional_answers.answer: YES/PARTIAL — cafeteria access could plausibly have a causal effect on weight change.
conditional_answers.rationale: If Z is ruled out, the cafeteria becomes a credible cause.

wise_refusal: To attribute the effect to the cafeteria, you must rule out role/location differences in who is placed in each building or vary cafeteria access independently (e.g., randomized rollout).
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: If building assignment is non-random, role/location confounding can produce a spurious cafeteria effect.

gold_rationale: If employees are assigned to buildings based on role/location, those factors can influence both cafeteria access and weight-related behaviors. Without blocking that backdoor path, the cafeteria-specific causal claim is not identified.

scenario: After getting a severe migraine on a particularly hot day, Theo starts drinking more water. Over the next two weeks, Theo has no migraines and concludes: “Drinking more water prevents my migraines.”
claim: Drinking more water will prevent Theo’s migraines.

Y.name: Migraine occurrence over the next two weeks

Z.name: Extreme heat/dehydration trigger and natural fluctuation in migraine frequency

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an extreme trigger prompts increased hydration; migraines may subside as conditions normalize).
key_insight: Starting a new habit right after an extreme episode can make natural reversion look like treatment success.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the migraine associated with unusual heat/conditions that did not persist over the next two weeks?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—it happened on a particularly hot day; conditions later were more typical.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the migraine was largely triggered by an unusual heat/dehydration day that did not repeat
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the migraine-free period does not prove water prevented migraines.
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression to baseline and disappearance of the trigger can explain improvement.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if migraines were frequent under similar conditions and repeatedly decreased only when hydration increased (tracked over multiple cycles)
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — hydration might help, but needs controlled tracking.
conditional_answers.rationale: Repeated comparable comparisons reduce (but don’t eliminate) regression and confounding explanations.

wise_refusal: Migraines fluctuate and depend on triggers (heat, sleep, stress, diet). To infer causation, track comparable weeks with and without increased hydration while controlling major triggers, or use an AB/crossover plan.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Extreme episode followed by natural improvement can mimic a prevention effect.

gold_rationale: A severe migraine during unusual heat can be followed by a quieter period even without increased water. A single before/after episode cannot establish prevention.

scenario: A remote worker notices: on days they wear noise-cancelling headphones, they finish more tasks. They conclude: “Noise-cancelling headphones make me more productive,” and tell coworkers to always wear them.
claim: Wearing noise-cancelling headphones will increase productivity.

Z.name: Day-level context (noise level, task type/difficulty, meeting load, urgency)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (context influences both whether headphones are used and how many tasks get done)
key_insight: Tool usage is often chosen in response to context; observational comparisons conflate tool effects with context effects.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are headphones more likely to be worn on days with more noise, deeper focus work, or higher urgency?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—headphone use often responds to workload/noise conditions.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if headphone use is chosen based on day difficulty/noise/task mix that also affects completion
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the observation does not identify a causal effect of headphones.
conditional_answers.rationale: Endogenous adoption confounds the relationship.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if headphone use is randomly assigned/alternated on comparable days and increases tasks completed
conditional_answers.answer: YES/PARTIAL — headphones could causally improve focus for some work types.
conditional_answers.rationale: A crossover or randomized schedule isolates the effect.

wise_refusal: To test causality, alternate headphone use on comparable days (similar meetings and task mix) or run an AB schedule. Otherwise context-driven usage can bias conclusions.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Context (noise/task mix/meeting load) drives both headphone use and productivity measures, making naive comparisons unreliable.

gold_rationale: Headphones may be used when the day’s context differs (noise, focus work, urgency), which also affects productivity. Without exogenous variation in headphone use, you can’t claim they cause higher task completion.

scenario: After several weeks of poor sleep, Sam buys blackout curtains. The following week, Sam sleeps better. Sam concludes: “Blackout curtains fix insomnia,” and recommends them as the solution.
claim: Installing blackout curtains will fix insomnia.
