Y.name: Sleep quality in the following week

Z.name: Insomnia severity fluctuation and concurrent routine changes (stress, caffeine, bedtime hygiene) prompting the purchase

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (a bad insomnia stretch triggers buying curtains; sleep may improve as the bad stretch ends and routines shift)
key_insight: Buying a solution during a bad stretch can make subsequent natural improvement look like a strong treatment effect.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were the curtains purchased during an unusually bad period of sleep that might have improved anyway?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the purchase was prompted by a bad period of sleep.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if insomnia fluctuates and Sam also changed other habits (caffeine, bedtime, stress) around the same time
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the improvement can’t be attributed to curtains alone.
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression and co-interventions can explain better sleep.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Sam tested curtains vs no curtains on comparable nights while holding other factors stable and repeatedly slept better with curtains
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — curtains may help if light was a key trigger, but effect varies.
conditional_answers.rationale: Within-person controlled comparisons better isolate the causal mechanism.

wise_refusal: Curtains might help if light is the trigger, but the before/after story is confounded by symptom fluctuation and other changes. Use comparable nights with/without curtains while tracking caffeine, bedtime, stress, and noise.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Intervention initiated during a bad stretch; improvement may reflect reversion and concurrent habit changes, not curtains alone.

gold_rationale: This is intervention-at-extremes regression: curtains were adopted after weeks of poor sleep, and sleep can improve as the bad period ends or other routines change. The strong claim that curtains 'fix insomnia' isn’t supported without controlled comparison.

scenario: A driving school analyzes only students who passed the road test. Among passers, those who practiced more hours report making more minor mistakes during lessons. The school concludes: “More practice causes more mistakes,” and suggests students should practice less to avoid errors.
claim: Reducing practice hours will reduce mistakes because practice causes mistakes.

Z.name: Passing the road test (selection variable)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (passing depends on enough practice and/or low mistakes; conditioning on Z can induce spurious relationships)
key_insight: Passer-only analyses can manufacture misleading relationships between variables that influence passing.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the analysis conditioned on students who passed the road test, excluding those who failed?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—only students who passed are included.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if passing depends on both practice exposure and mistake rate and the analysis conditions on passing
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the within-passers association does not imply practice causes mistakes.
conditional_answers.rationale: Passing is a collider; conditioning can induce spurious correlations (Berkson’s paradox).

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if you include all students and track mistakes longitudinally as practice increases within the same learner
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — practice may increase opportunities for mistakes short-term but reduce mistakes with learning over time.
conditional_answers.rationale: The causal effect may be non-linear; needs longitudinal or experimental evidence.

wise_refusal: Passer-only data can mislead. Include both passers and failers and study within-student changes as practice accumulates, or randomize extra practice assignments to identify causal effects.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on passing (collider) can reverse or distort the apparent practice–mistakes relationship.

gold_rationale: This is collider bias (Berkson’s paradox): restricting to students who pass conditions on a variable influenced by practice and mistakes, which can induce spurious patterns. The recommendation to practice less is not supported.

scenario: A relationship researcher surveys only couples who have been married for at least 10 years. In this sample, couples who report arguing more also report higher relationship satisfaction. The researcher concludes: “Arguing increases satisfaction,” and suggests couples should argue more to strengthen relationships.
claim: Encouraging couples to argue more will increase relationship satisfaction.

Z.name: Remaining married 10+ years (survivorship/selection into sample)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (staying married depends on conflict patterns and satisfaction; conditioning on Z can distort X–Y)
key_insight: Survivorship can make harmful behaviors look beneficial because couples harmed by them may have already exited the sample (divorced).

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the survey restricted to couples who stayed married 10+ years, excluding couples who divorced earlier?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—only long-term marriages are surveyed.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if high-conflict, low-satisfaction couples are more likely to divorce and thus are excluded
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the survivor-sample association does not imply arguing causes satisfaction.
conditional_answers.rationale: Survivorship/selection can induce misleading correlations.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if you include divorced couples (or model attrition) and distinguish constructive vs destructive conflict and still find constructive conflict improves satisfaction
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — conflict type matters and the effect must be causally evaluated.
conditional_answers.rationale: Handling selection and mechanism heterogeneity is necessary for causal claims.

wise_refusal: A survivor-only sample omits couples who left. To assess causality, include broader samples, account for attrition/divorce, and separate constructive conflict from destructive arguing before recommending behavior change.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on long-term marriage (a survivorship gate) can distort the relationship between arguing and satisfaction.

gold_rationale: This is survivorship/selection bias: only couples who stayed married are included, while couples whose arguing reduced satisfaction may have divorced and are missing. Therefore the observed correlation does not justify encouraging couples to argue more.

scenario: A friend says: people who use a language-learning app daily tend to become fluent faster. They conclude: “If you install this app, you will become fluent.” But the most motivated learners both use the app more and practice speaking outside the app.
claim: Using the language-learning app daily will cause faster conversational fluency.

Z.name: Learner motivation/commitment

trap.subtype_name: Motivated learners do more of everything

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (motivation drives app use and additional practice that accelerates fluency)
key_insight: Tools correlate with success because motivated users adopt them and also do other effective behaviors.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do daily app users differ in baseline motivation/commitment compared to non-users?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—motivation likely differs and also drives outside practice.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if motivation differs across app users and non-users and is not controlled
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the causal claim about the app alone is not supported.
conditional_answers.rationale: Z confounds the relationship between app usage and fluency speed.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if learners are matched/randomized on baseline motivation and total practice time
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the app may help, but effect depends on usage quality and complementary practice.
conditional_answers.rationale: Causal identification requires controlling Z and measuring mechanisms.

wise_refusal: You can’t isolate the app’s effect from motivation and overall practice. Compare learners with similar motivation and total practice time, or run an experiment assigning app access while tracking total practice.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Motivation/commitment drives both app usage intensity and fluency outcomes.

gold_rationale: Daily app users differ systematically from others in motivation and total practice, which can drive fluency. Therefore the observational correlation does not prove the app causes faster fluency on its own.

scenario: A school district notices that classes held in rooms with better ventilation have fewer reported colds. The district proposes: “If we install better ventilation, colds will decrease.” But the best-ventilated rooms are also newer, less crowded, and used by teachers who enforce stricter sick policies.
claim: Installing better ventilation will reduce colds in classrooms.

Y.name: Number of colds reported in a class

Z.name: Classroom environment quality (crowding, building condition, teacher policies)

trap.subtype_name: Ventilation correlated with crowding and policies

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (higher-quality/less crowded rooms have better ventilation and also fewer transmissions)
key_insight: Infrastructure differences bundle multiple factors that affect disease spread; ventilation effects must be isolated from correlated classroom conditions.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are well-ventilated rooms also systematically less crowded/newer or associated with different teacher policies?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—those correlated features are present in the observation.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if crowding and policies differ systematically across rooms and are not controlled
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the causal claim about ventilation alone is not identified.
conditional_answers.rationale: Z confounds the ventilation–colds association.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if ventilation is upgraded within the same rooms while crowding and policies remain similar (pre/post with controls)
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — ventilation could reduce colds, but effect must be estimated with appropriate controls.
conditional_answers.rationale: Within-room changes reduce confounding from fixed room differences.

wise_refusal: Room-level comparisons are confounded by crowding, building condition, and policies. Use within-room upgrades or randomized rollout to isolate ventilation’s effect on colds.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Ventilation correlates with other room/class factors that affect infection rates, confounding causal claims.

gold_rationale: Better ventilation may help, but the observed association can be explained by correlated differences like crowding and teacher policies. Without isolating ventilation changes, the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: A creator notices that after a week with unusually low social media engagement, they changed their posting time to mornings. The next week, engagement increased. They conclude: “Posting in the morning increases engagement,” and recommend that schedule to everyone.
claim: Changing posting time to mornings will increase engagement.

Z.name: Unusually low engagement week due to random fluctuation

trap.subtype_name: Schedule change after an unusually bad week

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an unusually low week triggers schedule change; engagement often rebounds)
key_insight: Changing strategy after an unusually bad outcome can make natural rebound look like strategy success.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the posting-time change made right after an unusually low-engagement week (an outlier)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—the change was triggered by an unusually low week.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if engagement varies widely week-to-week and the low week was an outlier
conditional_answers.answer: NO — the rebound does not prove mornings caused the increase.
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression to the mean and random fluctuation can explain improvement.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the creator alternated posting times across comparable weeks and mornings consistently performed better
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — mornings may help, but effect should be estimated with repeated tests.
conditional_answers.rationale: A crossover design can separate timing effects from random fluctuations.

wise_refusal: One switch after an unusually bad week is not enough. Use repeated A/B weeks or randomized posting times while keeping content quality constant to infer causal effects of timing.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Outcome-triggered strategy change + natural variability yields a spurious causal narrative about posting time.

gold_rationale: Because the schedule change was triggered by an unusually low week, a subsequent rebound is expected even without a true timing effect. This is regression to the mean; repeated controlled comparisons are needed to support a causal claim.

scenario: Jules missed a morning flight because of unexpected traffic and long security lines. Jules says: “If I had left home 30 minutes earlier, I would have made the flight.”
claim: If Jules had left 30 minutes earlier, Jules would have made the flight.

Z.name: Severity and timing of traffic/security delays and the boarding cutoff

causal_structure: X affects Y only relative to delay processes Z that may vary with time; the counterfactual depends on how delays shift
key_insight: Leaving earlier helps only if it changes the realized delays enough; some delays may persist or shift, making the claim conditional.

hidden_timestamp.question: Would leaving 30 minutes earlier have changed the realized traffic and security delays enough to reach the gate before boarding closed?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—delay dynamics and boarding cutoff timing are not established.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the delays were near-threshold and leaving 30 minutes earlier would place Jules ahead of the security surge and before boarding closed
conditional_answers.answer: VALID (conditional) — leaving earlier could plausibly make the flight.
conditional_answers.rationale: If the only difference is arriving before the bottleneck, the causal pathway exists.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if delays were severe (e.g., multi-hour security outage) or boarding closed well before Jules could arrive even with a 30-minute head start
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — leaving 30 minutes earlier would not be sufficient.
conditional_answers.rationale: If Z dominates, changing X by 30 minutes does not change Y.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on how delays would have unfolded if Jules left earlier and on the boarding cutoff. Without knowing whether 30 minutes is enough to clear the bottleneck, the claim is conditional.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Making the flight depends on delay processes (traffic, security) and boarding cutoff timing; leaving earlier helps only under certain delay conditions.

gold_rationale: The statement is conditional. Leaving earlier can increase the chance of making the flight, but whether 30 minutes is enough depends on the severity and timing of delays and the boarding cutoff. Without that information, you cannot assert the counterfactual as certain.

scenario: Taylor considered buying a stock last year but did not. The stock later increased significantly. Taylor says: “If I had bought it last year, I would have made a lot of money.”
claim: If Taylor had bought the stock last year, Taylor would have made a lot of money.

Y.name: Making a lot of money from the stock

Z.name: Holding/selling behavior (whether Taylor would have held through volatility and sold after the rise)

causal_structure: X affects Y only under assumptions about holding/selling behavior and transaction timing
key_insight: Profit is not determined solely by buying; it depends on whether and when the person would sell and how they would react to volatility.

hidden_timestamp.question: Would Taylor have held the stock until after the price increase, or could Taylor have sold earlier during volatility?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—Taylor’s holding/selling behavior is not established.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Taylor would have held until the later higher price and sold after the increase
conditional_answers.answer: VALID (conditional) — buying earlier would likely yield a profit.
conditional_answers.rationale: Given that holding path, the counterfactual aligns with realized price movement.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Taylor would have panic-sold during a drawdown or sold before the increase
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — Taylor might not have made a lot of money.
conditional_answers.rationale: Different selling timing breaks the assumed path to profit.

wise_refusal: This claim depends on Taylor’s future actions (holding and selling) and risk tolerance. Without specifying that Taylor would have held through volatility and sold after the rise, the counterfactual is conditional.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Buying is necessary but not sufficient for profit; profit depends on holding/selling decisions and timing.

gold_rationale: The statement is conditional. If Taylor would have held until the later price increase, profit is plausible. But if Taylor would have sold earlier (especially during volatility), the claimed profit may not occur. The counterfactual cannot be asserted without assumptions about holding behavior.

scenario: On the day of an important afternoon presentation, Morgan skipped lunch and felt unfocused. Morgan says: “If I had eaten lunch, I would have delivered a much better presentation.”
claim: If Morgan had eaten lunch, Morgan would have delivered a much better presentation.

Z.name: Stress/anxiety level that day (affecting appetite/decision to eat and performance)

trap.subtype_name: Shared cause affects both action and outcome across worlds

causal_structure: Z affects both X and Y; changing X may help but not necessarily overcome stress/anxiety effects
key_insight: Eating could help energy, but performance depends on stress/anxiety and preparation; the counterfactual is conditional on what else remains fixed.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was Morgan’s poor performance primarily driven by skipping lunch, or by stress/anxiety factors that would persist even if Morgan ate?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—stress/anxiety and preparation quality are not established.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Morgan was well-prepared and calm, and the main issue was low energy from skipping lunch
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL — eating lunch could plausibly improve performance.
conditional_answers.rationale: If lunch is the primary driver of energy/focus, changing it can improve Y.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Morgan was highly anxious or underprepared (dominant cause of performance) regardless of lunch
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — lunch would not necessarily yield a much better presentation.
conditional_answers.rationale: If Z dominates, changing X has limited impact on Y.

wise_refusal: You can’t be sure lunch would have made the presentation “much better” without knowing what primarily drove performance (energy vs stress/preparation). At best, the counterfactual is conditional on those factors being similar.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Stress/anxiety affects lunch decision and performance; lunch may affect focus but not deterministically.

gold_rationale: This counterfactual is conditional. Eating lunch might improve energy and focus, but performance also depends heavily on stress/anxiety and preparation. Without evidence that lunch was the main limiting factor, the claim cannot be asserted as certain.

scenario: During a tense project thread, Devon replied quickly with a blunt message. The next day, the team lead escalated the issue. Devon says: “If I had not replied, the escalation would not have happened.”
claim: If Devon had not replied, the issue would not have been escalated.

X.name: Devon not replying to the thread

Z.name: Issue severity / escalation inevitability (lead intent, deadlines, policy constraints)

causal_structure: X may influence Y only if escalation is sensitive to the reply; if escalation is driven by issue severity/prior intent (Z), changing X may not change Y
key_insight: Not replying could change tone dynamics, but escalation may have been inevitable due to severity or prior decisions.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was escalation already likely due to issue severity or the lead’s prior intent, regardless of Devon’s reply?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown—lead intent and severity thresholds are not established.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the lead was already planning to escalate due to severity or deadlines regardless of the reply
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — not replying would not prevent escalation.
conditional_answers.rationale: If Z dominates, changing Devon’s reply does not change the escalation decision.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the escalation was triggered specifically by Devon’s blunt reply (tone escalation) and the issue was otherwise manageable
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL — not replying could plausibly reduce the chance of escalation.
conditional_answers.rationale: If Devon’s message was the decisive trigger, removing it can change outcomes.

wise_refusal: This is conditional. Without knowing whether escalation was already likely due to severity/prior decisions, you can’t claim not replying would have prevented it. You’d need evidence that the reply was the main trigger.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Escalation depends on issue severity and leader intent; a reply may influence escalation only in some cases.

gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. If escalation was driven by severity or pre-existing intent, Devon’s reply would not be decisive. Only if the reply directly caused escalation (e.g., by escalating tone) would the counterfactual likely hold.

scenario: When choosing a college major, Pri chose Art History. Years later, Pri feels financially stressed and says: “If I had majored in Computer Science, I would be earning much more now.”
claim: If Pri had majored in Computer Science, Pri would be earning much more now.

causal_structure: Changing major affects earnings through many downstream steps; the counterfactual depends on whether Pri would succeed and follow the CS path
key_insight: A major is not a deterministic switch: earnings depend on aptitude, persistence, internships, and job opportunities; thus the claim is conditional.

hidden_timestamp.question: Would Pri have been able to complete a CS major successfully and pursue a CS career path (internships, jobs) under the counterfactual?

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Pri would have disliked CS, struggled to complete it, or chosen a different career path anyway
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional) — earnings would not necessarily be much higher.
conditional_answers.rationale: Without successful completion and career follow-through, the earnings difference may not materialize.

wise_refusal: This is conditional on whether Pri would have completed CS and followed the CS career pipeline. Major choice affects opportunities, but outcomes depend on skills, persistence, and job market dynamics. Without those assumptions, the claim isn’t certain.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Major choice can affect earnings, but the counterfactual hinges on latent aptitude/interest and downstream career steps.

gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. A CS major can increase earnings opportunities, but only if Pri would successfully complete the major and pursue a CS career path. Without establishing those assumptions, you cannot assert Pri would be earning much more with certainty.

scenario: A gym posts that members who take the “advanced HIIT” class have lower body fat than members who don’t. The post concludes: “HIIT classes reduce body fat.”
claim: Taking the advanced HIIT class reduces body fat.

key_insight: Self-selection into an intense class can explain the association without the class being the cause.

conditional_answers.answer: NO

conditional_answers.rationale: A causal effect would be plausible but requires controlled estimation.

label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Motivation/fitness influences both class choice and body fat; simple comparisons are confounded.

gold_rationale: Advanced HIIT participants are likely already more fit and motivated, with better diet adherence. Without controlling these factors or randomizing class participation, the observed association does not establish that HIIT caused lower body fat.

scenario: A sleep blog reports that among people who consult a sleep specialist, those who take prescription sleep medication report worse sleep quality than those who don’t. The blog concludes: “Sleep medication makes sleep worse.”
claim: Prescription sleep medication makes sleep worse.

Z.name: Baseline insomnia severity (indication) that drives medication decisions and predicts worse sleep

trap.subtype_name: More severe cases are more likely treated

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (worse baseline insomnia leads to medication and also predicts worse sleep outcomes)
key_insight: Treatment is often given to people with worse baseline problems; naive comparisons can wrongly blame the treatment.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if severity is comparable (or randomized) and medication worsens objective sleep measures
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: A causal harm effect would require controlled evidence.

wise_refusal: Among specialist patients, medication is typically used for harder cases. To judge medication effects, compare people with similar baseline severity or use randomized/within-person crossover evidence.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Severity drives both treatment and outcomes; observational comparisons can invert the causal story.

gold_rationale: This is indication bias (endogeneity): patients prescribed medication likely had worse insomnia at baseline, which predicts poorer reported sleep even after treatment. The association does not show the medication causes worse sleep.

scenario: After a week of unusually high stress at work, Nia starts using a guided-breathing app every evening. The following week is calmer and Nia feels less anxious. Nia claims: “The breathing app reduced my anxiety.”
claim: Using the guided-breathing app reduced Nia’s anxiety.

Z.name: Work stress intensity that week (an outlier week triggering behavior change)

trap.subtype_name: Intervention starts after an extreme stress week

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extreme stress triggers app adoption; anxiety falls when stress returns toward normal)
key_insight: Starting a coping tool after an extreme week can make natural recovery look like a treatment effect.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the app started right after an unusually stressful week that did not persist?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; stress the following week was lower.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the prior week was an outlier and the following week would have been calmer anyway
