conditional_answers.rationale: Regression to baseline stress can explain reduced anxiety.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Nia alternated app use across comparable weeks (similar stress) and anxiety reliably decreased on app weeks
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: A within-person crossover can better isolate the app’s causal effect.

wise_refusal: Anxiety can track workload cycles. To infer a causal effect, test the app across multiple comparable weeks or randomize/alternate usage while tracking stressors.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Outlier stress triggers adoption and predicts natural reduction in anxiety when stress normalizes.

gold_rationale: This is a classic regression-to-the-mean pattern: an intervention begins after an extreme stress period, followed by improvement as conditions revert. One before/after comparison cannot attribute the change to the breathing app.

scenario: A manager notices: teams that use a new project-tracking tool have fewer missed deadlines. The manager proposes mandating the tool for all teams to reduce missed deadlines.
claim: Mandating the project-tracking tool will reduce missed deadlines.

Z.name: Team maturity and management quality (planning discipline, staffing stability)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (mature teams choose tools and also hit deadlines)
key_insight: Good teams adopt tools; tools may be correlated with success without being the cause.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are teams using the tool already more mature (better staffing/planning) than teams not using it?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; adoption is not random.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if mature teams are more likely to adopt the tool and also miss fewer deadlines regardless
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Confounding by team maturity prevents causal attribution to the tool.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the tool is rolled out randomly or staggered and deadlines improve after rollout controlling for team trends
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: A causal effect is plausible but requires causal rollout evaluation.

wise_refusal: Mandating a tool based on correlational comparisons can fail if adoption reflects team maturity. Use a staggered rollout or randomized adoption to estimate the tool’s causal impact.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Team maturity influences both tool adoption and deadline performance.

gold_rationale: Tool usage is likely endogenous to team maturity and management quality. Without a causal rollout design, you can’t conclude that mandating the tool will reduce missed deadlines.

scenario: A nutrition influencer says: “People who take ‘detox tea’ report less bloating.” They recommend that everyone drink detox tea to reduce bloating.
claim: Drinking detox tea reduces bloating.

Z.name: Health-conscious “reset” behaviors (reduced salt/processed foods, increased water, fewer trigger foods) that co-occur with starting detox tea

trap.subtype_name: Tea adoption bundled with diet/hydration changes

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (a wellness reset drives both tea use and reduced bloating)
key_insight: If starting tea coincides with diet/hydration changes that affect bloating, you can’t attribute improvement to tea alone.

hidden_timestamp.question: Did the bloating improvement coincide with broader diet/hydration changes rather than tea itself?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely; tea adoption is commonly bundled with other changes.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if tea adopters also reduce salt/processed foods and increase hydration around the same time
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Bundled co-interventions confound the tea–bloating relationship.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if tea is tested against placebo while holding diet/hydration constant and bloating decreases more with tea
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: A causal effect would require controlled evidence; many ‘detox’ claims fail under controls.

wise_refusal: Bloating varies with salt, hydration, fiber, alcohol, sleep, stress, and menstrual cycle. To attribute changes to tea, keep diet constant and compare tea vs placebo (or randomized crossover).
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Tea use is a marker of a broader wellness reset that itself reduces bloating.

gold_rationale: The influencer’s evidence is observational and likely confounded: people who start detox tea often simultaneously change diet and hydration in ways that reduce bloating. Without isolating tea from those co-interventions, the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: A clinic compares patients who use a new migraine injection to patients who don’t. Injection users report more migraine days. A nurse concludes: “The injection increases migraines, so we should stop using it.”
claim: Using the migraine injection increases migraine frequency.

Z.name: Baseline migraine severity / refractoriness that triggers prescribing the injection

trap.subtype_name: Sicker patients are selected into injection

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (more severe patients are treated and also have more migraine days)
key_insight: Treated vs untreated comparisons can make effective treatments look harmful when treatment is targeted to worse cases.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the injection preferentially prescribed to patients with more severe or refractory migraines?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes, typically; severity drives treatment selection.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if injections are prescribed mainly to high-severity/refractory patients
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Indication bias explains why injection users have more migraine days.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if severity is balanced (randomized trial or strong adjustment) and injection users still have more migraine days
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: That would suggest possible harm, but would need careful causal evidence.

wise_refusal: Don’t infer harm from treated-vs-untreated clinic comparisons. Use randomized trials or strong causal designs (e.g., within-patient baselines plus comparable controls) adjusting for severity and escalation rules.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Severity drives both injection use and migraine frequency, biasing observational comparisons.

gold_rationale: Injection recipients are likely those with worse baseline migraines. Without controlling for baseline severity (or randomizing), you cannot conclude the injection increases migraines.

scenario: A dating coach looks only at people currently in relationships. Among those in relationships, people who text their partner less frequently report higher relationship satisfaction. The coach concludes: “Text less to be happier,” and sells a program to reduce texting.
claim: Reducing texting frequency increases relationship satisfaction.

Z.name: Being currently in a relationship (survivorship / selection gate)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (staying together depends on both satisfaction and communication dynamics; conditioning on Z distorts X–Y)
key_insight: Looking only at surviving relationships can hide breakups where low texting correlated with neglect and low satisfaction.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are relationships that ended (possibly due to low texting and low satisfaction) excluded from the dataset?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; the dataset only includes current relationships.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if low texting contributed to breakups that are excluded from the sample
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Conditioning on survival can flip or distort the observed association.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if you include ended relationships or run an experiment and find less texting improves satisfaction
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Effects may be context-dependent (distance, attachment style, conflict).

wise_refusal: Don’t infer what improves relationships from survivors-only data. Include ended relationships or test interventions; texting frequency is entangled with underlying dynamics.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on relationship survival induces spurious patterns among the remaining couples.

gold_rationale: This is survivorship/collider bias: analyzing only current couples can induce misleading associations between texting frequency and satisfaction. The coaching advice is not causally justified.

scenario: A university offers a free tutoring program. Students who attend tutoring more often have lower grades. An administrator concludes: “Tutoring makes grades worse,” and proposes cutting the program.
claim: Tutoring makes grades worse, so cutting tutoring will improve grades.

Z.name: Baseline academic struggle / prior low performance that increases tutoring attendance and predicts lower final grades

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (students who are struggling attend tutoring and also earn lower grades)
key_insight: Help-seeking is endogenous; naive attendee vs non-attendee comparisons can make support look harmful.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do students attend tutoring primarily because they are already struggling academically?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; need drives attendance.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if tutoring is used mostly by students with worse baseline performance
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Selection into tutoring explains the negative association.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if tutoring offers are randomized (or waitlist-based) and recipients improve relative to controls
conditional_answers.answer: YES/PARTIAL
conditional_answers.rationale: That would support a causal benefit of tutoring access.

wise_refusal: Don’t cut tutoring based on raw correlations. Use baseline controls, waitlists, RD at eligibility thresholds, or randomized tutoring offers to estimate causal impact.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Struggle drives both tutoring uptake and low grades; tutoring may help but is masked by selection.

gold_rationale: Students who attend tutoring are systematically those with lower baseline performance. The observed correlation does not show tutoring causes lower grades; it reflects selection/indication bias.

scenario: A city launches a bike-lane pilot in neighborhoods that already have high bike usage and strong pro-cycling community groups. After the pilot, bike commuting increases in those neighborhoods. The city claims: “The pilot caused the increase,” and uses it as proof the policy always works.
claim: The bike-lane pilot caused the increase in bike commuting.

Z.name: Pre-existing pro-cycling culture and upward pre-trend (used to choose pilot sites)

trap.subtype_name: Pilot placed where cycling already rising

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (site selection depends on culture/trends that also drive increases)
key_insight: Pilot placement is endogenous; success may reflect where the trend was already positive.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were pilot neighborhoods chosen because they already had high or rising cycling and strong advocates?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; selection is not random.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if pilot siting was driven by strong pre-trends and advocacy
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Endogenous placement confounds pilot effects with pre-existing trends.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if a diff-in-diff (or matched control) shows an additional increase beyond counterfactual trends
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Then a causal effect is plausible but must be estimated against the trend.

wise_refusal: Pilot outcomes in pre-selected areas don’t automatically generalize. Use matched comparison neighborhoods and pre-trend checks (diff-in-diff) to estimate incremental impact.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Neighborhood selection is driven by culture/trends that also increase cycling.

gold_rationale: Because pilot sites were chosen where cycling was already strong or increasing, post-pilot gains may reflect the existing trajectory rather than the policy’s causal effect. You need a counterfactual comparison.

scenario: A company studies only employees who received a promotion. Among promoted employees, those who worked the most overtime report lower job satisfaction. The company concludes: “Overtime reduces satisfaction,” and proposes banning overtime to improve morale.
claim: Banning overtime will improve job satisfaction because overtime reduces satisfaction.

Z.name: Promotion (conditioning on a selected subgroup)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (promotion depends on high effort/performance signals and also correlates with traits tied to satisfaction/engagement; conditioning on Z can induce spurious X–Y)
key_insight: Within a selected group (promoted employees), relationships between variables can be artifacts of selection.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is the analysis restricted only to employees who were promoted (conditioning on promotion)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; only promoted employees are included.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if promotion depends on performance/effort and correlates with engagement/satisfaction-related traits, and you condition on promotion
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Conditioning on a collider can induce misleading correlations.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if, in the full population with proper controls or within-person variation, overtime causally reduces satisfaction
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: A causal effect is plausible, but this promoted-only slice can’t identify it.

wise_refusal: Don’t infer overtime’s causal effect from promoted-only data. Analyze the full workforce and use designs that address selection and time trends (e.g., within-person changes, policy experiments).
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Promotion is a selection gate; conditioning on it can distort the overtime–satisfaction relationship.

gold_rationale: Restricting to promoted employees conditions on a selection variable influenced by multiple factors. This can induce spurious associations, so the evidence does not justify banning overtime.

scenario: A home-organization brand offers a paid “declutter challenge.” Participants report reduced stress after the program. The brand claims: “Paying for our declutter challenge reduces stress,” and encourages everyone to enroll.
claim: Enrolling in the declutter challenge reduces stress.

X.name: Enrolling in the paid declutter challenge

Z.name: Motivation/readiness to change plus time/resources (who is willing/able to enroll and follow through)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (motivated participants enroll and also reduce stress via multiple self-initiated actions)
key_insight: Testimonials from self-selected participants are not causal evidence of program impact.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are enrollees systematically more motivated or have more time/resources than non-enrollees?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; pay/time requirements screen participants.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if motivation/time/resources drive both enrollment and stress reduction behaviors
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Self-selection confounds the enrollment–stress relationship.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if access is randomized (e.g., lottery/free offer) and stress decreases more for treated group
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Then a causal effect is plausible but must be measured with controls.

wise_refusal: To test impact, compare to a randomized waitlist/control group (or lottery access). Before/after testimonials alone can’t isolate program causality.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Motivation/resources drive both participation and downstream stress reduction.

gold_rationale: People who enroll are self-selected and likely differ in motivation and available time, which also predicts stress reduction. Without a control group, the program’s causal effect is not established.

scenario: An HR team uses ‘badge swipes’ as a measure of office presence. They observe that employees with more badge swipes have higher performance ratings. HR concludes: “Forcing employees to come to the office more will increase performance.”
claim: Forcing employees to come to the office more will increase performance ratings.

Z.name: Role type and evaluation norms (some roles require onsite work and are rated/managed differently)

trap.subtype_name: Role drives both presence and ratings

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (role requirements drive both badge swipes and rating dynamics)
key_insight: Badge swipes are a proxy that can reflect role requirements; cross-role correlations don’t identify policy effects.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are high-swipe employees concentrated in roles with different responsibilities and evaluation criteria?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; role requirements can explain both.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if role type/manager expectations drive both badge swipes and ratings
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Role confounding prevents causal attribution to presence.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if within the same role/team, increasing onsite days quasi-randomly increases ratings
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Some tasks may benefit from co-location, but it requires causal testing.

wise_refusal: Badge swipes are a noisy proxy and confounded by role. To test causality, compare within the same role/manager or run a controlled rollout rather than extrapolating from cross-role correlations.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Role type and evaluation criteria influence both presence and performance ratings.

gold_rationale: Employees with more badge swipes may simply be in roles with different expectations and rating practices. The observed correlation does not show that forcing more office presence will improve performance ratings.

scenario: A school introduces a new math app only in classrooms where teachers volunteered early for pilots. After the pilot, those classrooms show improved test scores. The district claims: “The app caused the improvement.”
claim: The math app caused improved test scores.

X.name: Using the new math app (pilot classrooms)

Z.name: Teacher enthusiasm/skill and implementation quality (volunteer effect) correlated with pilot participation

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (enthusiastic teachers volunteer and also improve outcomes)
key_insight: Volunteer pilots can conflate app effects with teacher quality and implementation intensity.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were pilot classrooms chosen via teacher volunteering rather than random assignment?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; volunteers were used.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if volunteer teachers differ in enthusiasm/quality from non-volunteers
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Volunteer selection confounds app adoption and score gains.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if rollout is randomized across comparable classrooms and scores improve more with the app
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Then a causal effect is plausible under randomized evaluation.

wise_refusal: Volunteer pilots often overstate effects. Use randomized rollout or matched controls and verify pre-trends to separate teacher/implementation effects from the app’s impact.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Teacher enthusiasm drives both volunteering and improved outcomes; app effects are confounded.

gold_rationale: Because pilot teachers volunteered, they likely differ systematically in enthusiasm and implementation quality. Score gains cannot be attributed solely to the app without controlled rollout.

scenario: A personal finance blogger notes that people who automate their savings have higher account balances. The blogger claims: “If you turn on auto-savings, you will build wealth,” and sells a course on setting it up.
claim: Turning on auto-savings will cause higher account balances.

Z.name: Financial discipline / conscientiousness and income stability that increase both adoption and balances

trap.subtype_name: Discipline drives both auto-savings and balances

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (discipline/stability leads to auto-savings and higher balances)
key_insight: Auto-savings may help at the margin, but observational differences can mostly reflect who chooses to use it.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do auto-savers differ in discipline/income stability compared with non-auto-savers?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; those traits are rarely controlled.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if discipline/income stability primarily drives both adoption and balance growth
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Confounding prevents attributing the whole difference to auto-savings.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if a randomized nudge / within-person adoption (controlling income & spending shocks) increases net savings
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Auto-savings can reduce friction, but causal effect size requires proper identification.

wise_refusal: Auto-savings can reduce friction, but correlation isn’t causation. A causal estimate needs within-person comparisons with shock controls or randomized nudges.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Trait-like discipline/income stability confounds both auto-savings adoption and balances.

gold_rationale: People who turn on auto-savings often already have stable income and disciplined budgeting—factors that also predict higher balances. Without causal design, the claim that auto-savings causes higher balances is not established.

scenario: A hospital uses ambulance arrival as an ‘instrument’ for receiving a certain rapid-treatment pathway. They find patients who arrive by ambulance and receive rapid treatment have better outcomes, and conclude: “Rapid treatment caused better outcomes.” But arriving by ambulance can also directly reflect severity and faster triage beyond the pathway.
claim: The rapid-treatment pathway caused better outcomes because ambulance arrivals do better.

Z.name: Ambulance arrival (proposed instrument) that also reflects severity and can change care via other channels (triage priority, pre-hospital care)

trap.subtype_name: Instrument affects outcome through multiple paths / correlates with severity

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (ambulance arrival changes treatment probability and outcomes directly; IV assumptions fail)
key_insight: A valid instrument must affect the outcome only through treatment and be independent of unmeasured confounding—ambulance arrival usually violates both.

hidden_timestamp.question: Does ambulance arrival affect outcomes through channels other than the pathway (triage priority, pre-hospital interventions) or correlate with severity?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; these violations are likely.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if ambulance arrival directly changes outcomes (triage/pre-hospital care) or correlates with severity
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Exclusion/independence assumptions are violated; IV inference is invalid.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if ambulance arrival is effectively random and affects outcomes only via pathway assignment
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Then an IV design could work, but the assumptions are strong and unlikely.

wise_refusal: Ambulance arrival is usually not a valid instrument. Prefer randomized pathway assignment, RD on a threshold rule, or quasi-random capacity variation with careful checks.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Ambulance arrival changes assignment and outcomes via multiple channels; IV assumptions fail.

gold_rationale: The argument relies on an invalid instrument. Ambulance arrival is linked to severity and can alter outcomes through triage and pre-hospital care, so the association does not identify the pathway’s causal effect.

scenario: A company only surveys customers who contacted support. Among support-contact customers, those who received a refund report lower satisfaction than those who did not. The company concludes: “Refunds decrease satisfaction,” and considers limiting refunds.
claim: Limiting refunds will increase satisfaction because refunds decrease satisfaction.

Z.name: Problem/complaint severity among support contacts (more severe issues are more likely to get refunds and also depress satisfaction)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (severe complaints drive refunds and lower satisfaction)
key_insight: Within a complaints-only slice, remediation is assigned based on severity; raw comparisons can falsely blame the remedy.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are refunds more likely issued for the most severe problems (which also predict lower satisfaction)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; refund policy often escalates with severity.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if refund assignment is severity-based and severity also drives satisfaction
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Confounding by complaint severity explains the negative association.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if you randomize refund offers within matched complaint types/severity and refunds improve satisfaction
conditional_answers.answer: YES/PARTIAL
conditional_answers.rationale: That would support a causal positive effect of refunds for comparable issues.

wise_refusal: Don’t limit refunds based on severity-confounded comparisons. Match on complaint type/severity or run experiments (randomized goodwill credits) to estimate causal impact on satisfaction.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Refunds are allocated to worse problems; those problems also depress satisfaction.

gold_rationale: Refund recipients likely had more severe issues to begin with. Without controlling for complaint severity (or using experiments), the company cannot conclude refunds decrease satisfaction or that limiting refunds would help.

scenario: After a string of unusually bad customer reviews, a restaurant changes its menu layout. The next month reviews improve. The owner concludes: “Menu layout caused review improvement,” and recommends the change to other restaurants.
claim: Changing menu layout caused the improvement in reviews.

Y.name: Average customer review rating next month

Z.name: Outlier bad streak (random fluctuation and temporary service issues) that triggered the change and then naturally improved

trap.subtype_name: Change made at an extreme low point

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extreme low ratings trigger intervention; ratings rebound as noise/temporary issues resolve)
key_insight: Intervening after an unusually bad period often coincides with natural rebound, creating false attribution.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the change made right after an unusually bad streak likely to regress upward anyway?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; the timing suggests an extreme-triggered intervention.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the bad streak was driven by temporary issues/noise that resolved and reviews naturally rebounded
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Regression to the mean explains the apparent improvement.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if repeated A/B tests (or staggered rollouts) show layout changes consistently increase ratings
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Causality requires replication/controls beyond a single rebound.

wise_refusal: A single rebound after a bad streak doesn’t prove layout causality. Replicate across time/locations or A/B test menus to isolate the effect.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Extreme-triggered intervention plus expected rebound can mimic a causal effect.

gold_rationale: The menu change happened right after an unusually bad run, which is likely to improve due to regression to the mean and resolution of temporary issues. Without controlled testing, the causal claim is unsupported.

scenario: A company observes that employees who attend leadership training have higher promotion rates. The company concludes: “Leadership training causes promotions,” and decides to require the training for anyone who wants to be promoted.
claim: Requiring leadership training will cause higher promotion rates.

Z.name: High-potential identification and manager sponsorship (who is nominated/encouraged to attend training)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (sponsored/high-potential employees attend training and also get promoted more)
key_insight: Training participation can be a marker of sponsorship, not a driver of promotion.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are trainees nominated as high-potential employees rather than selected randomly?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; nomination/sponsorship often determines attendance.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if sponsorship/high-potential status drives both training attendance and promotions
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Selection bias: training isn’t exogenous.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if training is randomly offered within comparable groups and increases promotions holding sponsorship constant
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Training may help, but causal impact needs evaluation.

wise_refusal: Don’t equate correlation with causation when training is tied to sponsorship. Evaluate via randomized offers, staggered rollout, or matched comparisons controlling for sponsorship/performance.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Sponsorship influences who gets training and who gets promoted.

gold_rationale: Employees sent to leadership training are often already sponsored/high-potential, which independently increases promotion odds. Therefore requiring training based on this correlation does not establish it will cause promotions.

scenario: A hospital compares people who got a ‘priority bed assignment’ to those who did not. People with priority beds have higher survival. The hospital claims: “Priority bed assignment saves lives,” and wants to expand it. But priority beds are given to patients who arrive earlier and have certain characteristics; staffing levels vary by shift.
claim: Expanding priority bed assignment will save lives.

Z.name: Arrival time/shift staffing/triage pathway differences that affect both bed assignment and survival

trap.subtype_name: Bed assignment correlated with staffing and triage conditions

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (shift conditions affect bed assignment and outcomes)
key_insight: Operational policies are entangled with staffing and triage; naïve comparisons can misattribute effects to the policy.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do arrival time/shift staffing and triage rules influence both priority bed access and survival?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes; these operational conditions vary and can affect outcomes.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if priority beds are correlated with better-staffed shifts or earlier arrival/triage advantages
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Operational confounding prevents causal attribution to bed priority.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if bed priority is assigned quasi-randomly (lottery when scarce) and survival improves
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Then a causal benefit is plausible but requires a causal design.

wise_refusal: Before scaling, estimate causal impact using designs that handle triage/staffing confounds (RD at thresholds, lottery when beds scarce, or quasi-random capacity variation).
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Shift staffing and triage conditions influence both bed assignment and survival.

gold_rationale: Priority bed assignment is entangled with arrival time, staffing, and triage conditions that also affect survival. Without isolating assignment from those confounders, the hospital cannot conclude expanding priority beds will save lives.

scenario: A researcher studies only people who completed a 12-week running plan. Among completers, those who ran the most miles report more knee pain. The researcher concludes: “Running causes knee pain,” and recommends reducing mileage for everyone.
claim: Reducing running mileage will reduce knee pain because running causes knee pain.

Z.name: Completing the 12-week plan (conditioning on completion / attrition gate)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (completion depends on mileage tolerance and injury/pain; conditioning on Z biases mileage–pain among survivors)
key_insight: Completer-only analyses can hide dropouts due to pain and distort relationships among survivors.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were participants with high pain more likely to drop out and thus excluded from analysis?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely yes; the study includes only completers.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if completion depends on both mileage tolerance and pain (and analysis conditions on completion)
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Completion is a collider; restricting to completers can induce misleading associations.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if you include all participants and estimate the mileage→pain effect using longitudinal methods (handling attrition)
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Mileage may affect injury risk, but causal effect needs proper attrition handling or randomization.

wise_refusal: Avoid completer-only conclusions. Include dropouts and model attrition or randomize mileage targets to estimate causal impact on knee pain.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Completion depends on tolerance and pain; conditioning on it distorts observed mileage–pain among survivors.

gold_rationale: Because the analysis conditions on completion, it likely excludes people who dropped out due to pain. This selection can distort the relationship between mileage and pain, so the recommendation is not supported by the data slice.

scenario: On a day Pat felt unusually tired, Pat skipped the gym. Later that day, Pat felt guilty and said: “If I had gone to the gym, I would have had more energy afterward.”
claim: If Pat had gone to the gym, Pat would have had more energy afterward.

X.name: Going to the gym that day

Z.name: Cause of fatigue that day (illness, sleep debt, acute stress) which would persist across the counterfactual and also influenced skipping

trap.subtype_name: Effect depends on why Pat was tired

causal_structure: Z affects both X and Y; X may affect Y for some, but the counterfactual hinges on the dominant fatigue mechanism
key_insight: The same fatigue cause that drove skipping may also limit any energy boost from exercise, making the counterfactual conditional.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was Pat’s fatigue due to a cause (illness/severe sleep debt) that would keep energy low regardless of going?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown; the fatigue mechanism is not established.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Pat’s fatigue was mild and exercise reliably boosts Pat’s energy/mood
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Going could plausibly increase short-term energy via arousal/mood mechanisms.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Pat was sick or severely sleep-deprived such that energy would stay low regardless
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional)
conditional_answers.rationale: If Z dominates, changing X would not reliably change Y.

wise_refusal: This depends on why Pat was tired. Exercise can boost energy for some situations, but not when illness or severe sleep debt is the main driver.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Underlying fatigue cause drives both the decision and the outcome; the effect of gym is conditional on the mechanism.

gold_rationale: The counterfactual is conditional: going to the gym might increase energy via mood/arousal, but if fatigue was driven by illness or severe sleep debt, energy would likely remain low. Without knowing Z, the claim isn’t determinate.

scenario: Alex sent a job application two days before the deadline and got rejected. Alex says: “If I had applied earlier, I would have gotten an interview.”
claim: If Alex had applied earlier, Alex would have gotten an interview.

Z.name: Hiring process dynamics (rolling vs batch review, interview slots filling) and application competitiveness relative to the cutoff

trap.subtype_name: Outcome depends on review policy and near-threshold competitiveness

causal_structure: X may affect Y only under rolling review/capacity constraints and if application quality is near the decision threshold
key_insight: Earlier timing only helps if timing changes consideration (rolling slots) and the application was competitive; otherwise timing is irrelevant.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were interviews allocated on a rolling basis with slots filling early, and was Alex near the threshold?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown; both the review policy and competitiveness are unobserved.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the employer reviewed on a rolling basis, slots filled early, and Alex’s application was near-threshold
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Earlier timing could plausibly move the application into consideration before capacity filled.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if review was batched after the deadline or Alex’s application was uncompetitive regardless of timing
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional)
conditional_answers.rationale: Then earlier submission would not change the outcome.

wise_refusal: This depends on the hiring pipeline and how strong the application was. Without knowing whether timing mattered (rolling review) and whether Alex was near the cutoff, the counterfactual is conditional.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Timing can matter under rolling review, but quality and capacity constraints dominate.

gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. Earlier submission can help if the employer uses rolling review and Alex was close to the interview cutoff. If review is batched or the application was far below the threshold, timing would not change the outcome.

scenario: During a dinner argument, Casey raised their voice and the conversation escalated. Later Casey says: “If I had stayed calm, we would have resolved the disagreement peacefully.”
claim: If Casey had stayed calm, the disagreement would have been resolved peacefully.

Z.name: Partner’s emotional state and the underlying issue severity (whether conflict would escalate anyway)

causal_structure: X may influence Y, but Y also depends on Z (partner state and issue severity) which may overwhelm the effect
key_insight: Calmness can help, but whether peace is achieved depends on the other person and the issue’s intensity—so the counterfactual is conditional.

hidden_timestamp.question: Would the partner have remained escalated due to their own emotional state or issue severity regardless of Casey’s calmness?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown; partner state and issue severity are not established.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the partner was receptive and Casey’s raised voice was the main trigger for escalation
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Staying calm could plausibly prevent escalation and enable resolution.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the partner was already escalated or the issue was severe enough to escalate regardless
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional)
conditional_answers.rationale: If Z dominates, Casey’s calmness may not change the outcome.

wise_refusal: This depends on both people and the issue. Staying calm often helps, but it’s not sufficient if the other party is escalated or the issue is severe.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Conflict outcomes depend on both parties and issue severity; calmness is one factor, not determinative.

gold_rationale: The counterfactual is conditional. Calm behavior can reduce escalation risk, but peaceful resolution depends on the partner’s emotional state and the underlying issue severity. Without those details, it cannot be asserted as certain.

scenario: Jordan bought a used car and later faced expensive repairs. Jordan says: “If I had paid for a pre-purchase inspection, I would not have had these repair costs.”
claim: If Jordan had paid for a pre-purchase inspection, Jordan would not have had these repair costs.

Z.name: Detectability of the defect during inspection and Jordan’s willingness to walk away/negotiate

causal_structure: X can influence Y only if inspection would reveal the issue (Z) and Jordan would act on it
key_insight: An inspection doesn’t guarantee preventing repairs; it depends on whether the defect was detectable and whether it would change the purchase decision.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the defect detectable in a standard inspection, and would Jordan have declined the car or negotiated repair coverage?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown; detectability and decision response are not established.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the defect was detectable and Jordan would have walked away or negotiated repairs/price accordingly
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Inspection could plausibly prevent or offset repair costs by altering the purchase terms.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the defect was intermittent/hidden and not detectable, or Jordan would have bought anyway
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional)
conditional_answers.rationale: In that case, inspection would not prevent the later repair costs.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is conditional on detectability and on whether inspection results would change the purchase decision. Inspections reduce risk, but do not eliminate it.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Inspection only changes outcome if it detects the problem and changes the decision/terms.

gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. A pre-purchase inspection can reduce repair risk, but only if it would have detected the specific defect and if Jordan would have acted on the information. Without those assumptions, the counterfactual is not certain.

scenario: Lena didn’t attend a friend’s birthday party because of work. Later Lena felt left out and said: “If I had gone, my friendships would be stronger now.”
claim: If Lena had gone to the party, Lena’s friendships would be stronger now.

Z.name: Overall relationship investment pattern and friends’ perceptions over time (one event vs repeated engagement)

causal_structure: X may influence Y slightly, but Y depends heavily on Z (long-run engagement patterns and reciprocation)
key_insight: A single missed event may or may not matter; relationship strength depends on broader patterns and context.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was this party a rare pivotal event in the friendship group, or part of a broader pattern of missed vs attended events?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown; the broader trajectory is not established.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if this was a pivotal rare gathering and Lena’s absence changed others’ perceptions in a lasting way
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Attending could plausibly strengthen bonds if the event was uniquely important.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if friendships are driven by many interactions and one party would not materially change the trajectory
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional)
conditional_answers.rationale: A single event is unlikely to deterministically alter long-run relationship strength.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether the party was pivotal and on Lena’s overall engagement pattern. Friendships typically strengthen through repeated interactions, not one event alone.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Friendship strength is mainly driven by long-run interaction patterns; one event may have limited or context-dependent impact.

gold_rationale: The claim is conditional. Attending one party can help, especially if it is pivotal, but long-run friendship strength depends on broader engagement and reciprocal dynamics. Without knowing the context, the counterfactual cannot be asserted as certain.

scenario: Mira skipped breakfast and later felt irritable during a morning meeting. Mira says: “If I had eaten breakfast, I wouldn’t have been irritable.”
claim: If Mira had eaten breakfast, Mira would not have been irritable in the meeting.

Z.name: Stable blood sugar / reduced hunger during the morning

trap.subtype_name: Depends on which mechanism drove the outcome

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (breakfast stabilizes blood sugar; stable blood sugar reduces irritability)
key_insight: The counterfactual depends on whether breakfast would change the mediator (hunger/blood sugar) and whether that mediator drives irritability versus other stressors.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was irritability primarily driven by hunger/blood sugar or by meeting stress/conflict?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Mira’s irritability is typically hunger-driven and breakfast would prevent hunger
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Mediator change makes the counterfactual plausible.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if irritability was driven by meeting conflict/stress unrelated to hunger
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional)
conditional_answers.rationale: Even with breakfast, irritability could remain.

wise_refusal: Breakfast may reduce irritability via hunger/blood sugar, but if stressors drove mood, breakfast wouldn’t necessarily change it. The counterfactual is conditional on the mediator being the key driver.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Breakfast impacts mood through hunger/blood sugar mediator.

gold_rationale: This is a mediator-based counterfactual: breakfast would affect irritability through hunger/blood sugar. If hunger was the main cause, the claim holds; if not, it may not. Thus conditional.

scenario: Ravi didn’t practice piano this week and struggled at the lesson. Ravi says: “If I had practiced daily, I would have played the piece smoothly.”
claim: If Ravi had practiced daily, Ravi would have played the piece smoothly.

Y.name: Playing the piece smoothly at the lesson

Z.name: Skill consolidation / muscle memory from repeated practice

trap.subtype_name: Depends on which mechanism drove the outcome

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (daily practice builds consolidation; consolidation improves performance)
key_insight: Daily practice likely improves consolidation, but whether it would guarantee smooth playing depends on difficulty, technique, and practice quality.

hidden_timestamp.question: Would daily practice meaningfully improve consolidation given the piece’s difficulty and Ravi’s practice quality?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the main issue was lack of repetition and daily practice would build muscle memory
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Mediator change makes improved performance likely.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if the main issue was a technique flaw requiring targeted instruction, not repetition
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional)
conditional_answers.rationale: Practice alone may not fix the problem; mediator insufficient.

wise_refusal: Practice improves performance via consolidation, but outcomes depend on practice quality and whether technique issues exist. The counterfactual is conditional.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Practice affects performance mainly through consolidation mediator.

gold_rationale: The claim is conditional: daily practice can improve consolidation and performance, but it may not guarantee smooth execution if the problem is technique-specific or the piece is too hard. Mediator-based dependence makes it conditional.

scenario: Sam didn’t set an alarm and overslept, arriving late to work. Sam says: “If I had set an alarm, I wouldn’t have been late.”
claim: If Sam had set an alarm, Sam would not have been late.

Z.name: Waking up earlier (successful wake response)

trap.subtype_name: Outcome depends on whether the mechanism would change

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (alarm increases probability of waking earlier; waking earlier increases on-time arrival)
key_insight: An alarm doesn’t guarantee waking (snooze, hearing it). The counterfactual depends on whether the alarm would change the mediator (wake time).

hidden_timestamp.question: Would Sam have woken up when the alarm rang (not snoozed through it) and had enough time for commute?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Sam reliably wakes to alarms and waking earlier would provide enough buffer time
conditional_answers.answer: CONDITIONAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Mediator likely changes; on-time arrival plausible.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if Sam often sleeps through alarms or would still face delays (traffic, transit)
conditional_answers.answer: INVALID (conditional)
conditional_answers.rationale: Alarm may not change mediator enough to prevent lateness.

wise_refusal: Setting an alarm increases the chance of waking earlier, but the counterfactual depends on whether it would actually change Sam’s wake time and whether commute delays would still occur.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Alarm affects lateness through wake time mediator.

gold_rationale: This is a mediator-based counterfactual: alarm-setting affects wake time, which affects arriving on time. If Sam would respond to the alarm and have sufficient buffer, the claim holds; otherwise not. Conditional.

scenario: A hospital provides discharge checklists. After adopting checklists, readmissions decrease. Staff claim checklists reduce readmissions by improving patient understanding of medications and follow-up.
claim: Discharge checklists reduce readmissions.

Z.name: Improved patient understanding/adherence to post-discharge plan

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (checklists improve understanding/adherence; adherence reduces readmissions)
key_insight: If checklists are rushed or not understood, mediator fails; reductions require real comprehension and adherence support.

hidden_timestamp.question: Did patient understanding and adherence actually improve (teach-back, follow-up) after checklists?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Unknown.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if checklists are implemented with teach-back and measurably improve adherence
conditional_answers.answer: YES/PARTIAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Mediator supports reduced readmissions.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if checklists become box-checking with no comprehension gains
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Without mediator change, readmission reduction is not attributable.

wise_refusal: Checklists reduce readmissions only if they improve understanding and adherence. Measure mediator outcomes and use staggered adoption or RCTs to estimate causal impact.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Readmission effects are mediated by understanding and adherence.

gold_rationale: The plausible causal mechanism is improved post-discharge adherence (mediator). Without confirming mediator changes and controlling other changes, the claim remains conditional.

scenario: A runner logs their mile times for 30 days. On days right after an unusually fast mile (X = “great performance day”), the next day’s mile time (Y) is typically slower. The runner concludes: “My body naturally regresses after an unusually good day; one great time doesn’t imply I got permanently faster.”
claim: The pattern of a slower time after an unusually fast day can be explained by regression to the mean rather than a real performance decline caused by the fast day.

X.name: An unusually fast mile time (extreme good performance day)

Z.name: Random day-to-day fluctuation / measurement noise in performance

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extremes arise from noise; subsequent values are less extreme on average)
key_insight: Conditioning on an extreme observation makes the next observation look like a ‘reversal’ even if nothing causal happened.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was day-to-day performance noisy enough that extreme days occur by chance?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes (typical in repeated measures), so regression to mean is plausible.

wise_refusal: A slow day after a very fast day doesn’t by itself prove a causal ‘crash’; it often reflects normal variability and regression to the mean.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: X is defined as an extreme (unusually fast) measurement, so Z (noise) induces the apparent reversal in Y.

gold_rationale: Because X is selected as an extreme (unusually fast) outcome of a noisy process, the next-day time Y will typically be closer to the runner’s average even without any causal ‘recovery’ effect. The runner’s interpretation is a correct regression-to-mean explanation.

scenario: A student notices they study the most (X) on nights before their hardest exams, and they also feel the most stressed (Y) on those same nights. The student concludes: “Studying more isn’t necessarily causing the stress; the exam difficulty is driving both.”
claim: The correlation between studying more and higher stress can be explained by a common cause (exam difficulty) rather than studying causing stress.

X.name: Study time the night before an exam

Y.name: Stress level the night before an exam

Z.name: Exam difficulty / stakes

trap.subtype_name: Z causes both studying and stress

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (difficulty drives both behavior and emotion)
key_insight: A common cause can create an association between X and Y even if X does not cause Y.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do harder exams reliably cause both more studying and more stress?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes (plausible and often observed), so confounding is likely.

wise_refusal: Without controlling for exam difficulty (or randomizing study time), you can’t conclude that studying itself causes stress from correlation alone.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Difficulty is a classic confounder linking study time and stress.

gold_rationale: The student’s causal caution is correct: exam difficulty can drive both more studying and higher stress, producing a correlation that does not imply studying is the cause of stress.

scenario: A school district randomly assigns half of its middle schools to adopt a new reading curriculum (X) and keeps the rest on the old curriculum. After one semester, treated schools have higher reading scores (Y). The district concludes the new curriculum improved reading performance.
claim: Adopting the new reading curriculum increases reading scores.

Z.name: Student baseline reading ability / school resources

causal_structure: do(X) → Y (randomized assignment blocks confounding)
key_insight: Random assignment makes treated and control groups comparable on average, so score differences can be attributed to the curriculum.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was adoption randomized (not chosen by higher-performing schools)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—explicit random assignment.

wise_refusal: With random assignment and consistent testing, it’s reasonable to attribute average score gains to the curriculum, while still checking implementation fidelity and attrition.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Z may affect outcomes, but randomization prevents Z from determining X, supporting a causal interpretation of X → Y.

gold_rationale: Because curriculum adoption was randomized, confounders like baseline ability or resources should be balanced across groups on average. The observed difference in scores supports a causal effect of adopting the new curriculum.

scenario: A company notices that employees enroll in a stress-management program right after an unusually stressful month. In the following month, average stress scores are lower. The HR lead says: “We should not credit the program solely for the drop; some of it is likely regression to the mean.”
claim: The observed stress reduction after employees enroll could partly reflect regression to the mean rather than the program’s causal effect.

Z.name: Temporary stress spike / random fluctuation driving enrollment timing

trap.subtype_name: Enrollment triggered by an extreme period

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (spike triggers enrollment; stress naturally falls toward typical level)
key_insight: When intervention is triggered by extreme measurements, post-intervention improvements can occur even with zero treatment effect.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was enrollment typically prompted by unusually high stress periods?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—enrollment often follows spikes, making regression-to-mean a real concern.

wise_refusal: To estimate the program’s true effect, compare to a control group with similar pre-spike stress or randomize invitations; otherwise improvements can be confounded by regression to the mean.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Selection into X is partly driven by extreme Z, inducing apparent improvement in Y.

gold_rationale: The HR lead’s reasoning is correct: enrollment timing tied to stress spikes can make subsequent stress drop even without an effective program. Recognizing regression-to-mean is valid causal reasoning.

scenario: A city tests a new bike-lane design on a randomly selected set of comparable streets (X). After installation, near-miss incidents (Y) decrease on treated streets compared to untreated streets observed over the same period. The city claims the design improved safety.
claim: Installing the new bike-lane design reduces near-miss incidents.

Z.name: Traffic volume / seasonal cycling patterns

trap.subtype_name: Compare treated vs untreated same time

causal_structure: do(X) → Y with concurrent controls mitigating Z trends
key_insight: Concurrent untreated streets help rule out citywide seasonal changes as the explanation for improvements.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were untreated streets measured during the same period with the same near-miss definition?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—concurrent measurement is stated.

wise_refusal: The causal claim is supported by the randomized street selection and concurrent controls, but measurement consistency and spillovers (drivers rerouting) should still be checked.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Z may affect Y but is balanced/controlled via random assignment and concurrent untreated streets.

gold_rationale: Because the streets were randomly selected and compared to concurrent controls, the observed reduction in near-misses is strong evidence that the design caused improved safety on average.

scenario: A clinician is evaluating a new migraine medication (X). They note that patients usually seek treatment right after an unusually severe migraine week. The clinician says: “We should expect symptoms to improve next week even without medication, so we need a control group.”
claim: Without a control group, pre/post improvement after starting migraine medication may overstate efficacy due to regression to the mean.

Z.name: Severity spike triggering treatment-seeking (extreme baseline)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extreme baseline drives treatment and predicts natural improvement)
key_insight: Starting treatment at a symptom peak makes natural improvement look like a treatment effect.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do patients typically start medication right after unusually severe weeks?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—treatment-seeking is often triggered by peaks.

wise_refusal: A randomized trial or matched control group is needed to separate medication effects from natural symptom fluctuation and regression to the mean.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Selection on peaks produces apparent improvement post-treatment even if X has no effect.

gold_rationale: The clinician’s caution is correct: treatment initiation after an extreme symptom period creates regression-to-mean bias in pre/post comparisons. Requiring a control group is valid causal reasoning.

scenario: A teacher wants to know whether tutoring (X) improves math scores (Y). The teacher says: “If I only look at students who stayed in the tutoring program for the full semester (Z = ‘completed tutoring’), I may bias the results because struggling students might drop out.”
claim: Conditioning analysis on completing tutoring can introduce selection bias and distort the estimated tutoring effect.

Z.name: Completing tutoring (staying enrolled)

causal_structure: X → Z ← U and U → Y (conditioning on Z opens a backdoor via unobserved factors U)
key_insight: Restricting to people who ‘complete’ a program can create non-comparable groups if completion depends on unobserved factors related to outcomes.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do dropout/completion patterns depend on motivation or baseline difficulty that also affects scores?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—plausible, making selection bias likely.

wise_refusal: To estimate effect, analyze intent-to-treat or account for dropout mechanisms; conditioning only on completers can mislead.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on Z (completion) can open biasing paths through U.

gold_rationale: The teacher is correct that conditioning on completion can induce selection/collider bias if completion is influenced by factors that also affect performance. Recognizing this is valid.

scenario: A gym chain pilots an ‘attendance reminder’ text message (X) by randomly selecting half of new members to receive the messages. After 8 weeks, the treated group attends more sessions (Y). The chain concludes reminders increase attendance.
claim: Sending attendance reminder texts increases gym attendance.

Z.name: Baseline motivation

causal_structure: do(X) → Y (randomization supports causal inference)
key_insight: Random assignment of reminders isolates the effect from baseline motivation differences.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were reminders assigned randomly (not opt-in)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—randomly selected half of new members.

wise_refusal: Given randomization, the average attendance difference is attributable to reminders, assuming minimal spillover and consistent measurement.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Z may affect Y but does not drive X under random assignment.

gold_rationale: Because reminders were randomized, confounding by baseline motivation is mitigated. Observed higher attendance in the treated group supports the causal claim.

scenario: A homeowner tests whether a new air purifier (X) reduces indoor allergy symptoms (Y). They measure symptoms during a high-pollen week, buy the purifier, then measure again during a lower-pollen week. They say: “This is not a fair test because pollen levels changed.”
claim: Comparing symptoms before/after installing the purifier without accounting for changing pollen levels can confound the estimated purifier effect.

Z.name: Outdoor pollen level during measurement week

causal_structure: Z → Y and (time) → Z; naive pre/post mixes X effect with Z changes
key_insight: If background conditions shift, pre/post differences can reflect the background rather than the intervention.

hidden_timestamp.question: Did pollen levels differ substantially between the pre and post weeks?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—explicitly stated high vs lower pollen.

wise_refusal: To test the purifier’s effect, compare to a control period with similar pollen levels, randomize on/off days, or include concurrent controls.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Z affects Y and varies over time; naive pre/post conflates X with Z changes.

gold_rationale: The homeowner’s reasoning is correct: changing pollen levels can explain symptom improvement independent of the purifier, so the causal conclusion requires controlling for Z.

scenario: A student tries a new study app (X) right after receiving a very low quiz score. The next quiz score (Y) is higher. The student says: “Part of this improvement could be regression to the mean; I shouldn’t conclude the app caused the jump from one quiz.”
claim: A jump in score after a very low quiz can reflect regression to the mean, so one pre/post comparison is insufficient to claim the app caused improvement.

Z.name: Random fluctuation / unusually bad quiz day prompting app adoption

trap.subtype_name: Intervention starts after an extreme low outcome

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extreme low triggers adoption; scores naturally move toward average)
key_insight: Starting an intervention after an unusually poor outcome inflates apparent improvement.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the first quiz unusually low relative to typical performance?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—explicitly described as very low.

wise_refusal: To evaluate the app, use multiple quizzes, compare to a baseline trend, or include a control (e.g., classmates not using the app).
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Selection on an extreme low outcome produces apparent gains next time.

gold_rationale: The student’s caution is correct: regression to the mean can explain improvement from an extreme low score. One pre/post data point cannot identify the app’s causal effect.

scenario: A city offers free smoke alarms (X) and wants to know if they reduce fire-related injuries (Y). An analyst says: “If we only analyze homes that requested an alarm (Z = ‘requested’), we’ll bias results because riskier households may be more likely to request.”
claim: Restricting analysis to households that request alarms can bias the estimated effect of providing alarms.

Z.name: Requesting an alarm

causal_structure: X → Z ← U and U → Y (conditioning on Z opens bias via U)
key_insight: Self-selection into requesters can create non-comparability and distort causal inference.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are higher-risk households (older wiring, smokers) more likely to request alarms?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Plausible; thus restricting to requesters risks bias.

wise_refusal: A better design is randomized distribution, randomized encouragement, or intent-to-treat using assignment rather than request behavior.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Conditioning on Z (requesting) can open a backdoor path through U.

gold_rationale: The analyst’s warning is correct: conditioning on requesters (a selection variable influenced by risk factors) can induce bias and invalidate causal comparisons.

scenario: A researcher evaluates a sleep workshop (X) and proposes controlling for ‘sleep quality after the workshop’ (Z) when estimating the workshop’s effect on mood (Y). A colleague says: “Don’t control for post-treatment sleep quality; it’s part of the mechanism.”
claim: Controlling for post-treatment sleep quality can block part of the workshop’s effect on mood and bias the estimate (post-treatment adjustment).

Z.name: Sleep quality after attending the workshop

trap.subtype_name: Adjusting for Z that lies on the causal path

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (sleep quality mediates workshop’s impact on mood)
key_insight: Adjusting for a mediator removes part of the total effect and can introduce bias if Z has other causes related to Y.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is sleep quality measured after the intervention (post-treatment)?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—explicitly post-workshop.

wise_refusal: Estimate total effect without controlling for mediators; if you want direct effects, you need careful assumptions and design.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Z is downstream of X; controlling for it blocks the total effect path.

gold_rationale: The colleague is correct: post-treatment sleep quality is a mediator. Controlling for it biases the total effect estimate by blocking the causal pathway (and can introduce additional bias).

scenario: A company changes its customer support script (X) and sees customer satisfaction (Y) rise afterward. A manager says: “Before crediting the script, we should check whether there was also a product outage that ended (Z) right after we changed the script.”
claim: A concurrent change (like an outage ending) can confound a pre/post comparison, so attributing the satisfaction increase solely to the new script is not justified without controlling for the concurrent change.

Z.name: Product outage status / incident severity

trap.subtype_name: Another event changed at the same time

causal_structure: Z → Y; timing correlation between X and Z can misattribute cause
key_insight: When multiple things change at once, simple before/after attribution is unreliable.

hidden_timestamp.question: Did any major incident/outage or product change occur concurrently with the script rollout?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Possibly; manager is correctly checking.

wise_refusal: Use concurrent controls (e.g., teams not changing scripts) or staggered rollouts to isolate the script’s effect from incident resolution.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: If Z changes at the same time as X, naive pre/post can confound X’s effect.

gold_rationale: The manager’s reasoning is valid: a time-varying confounder (e.g., outage ending) can explain the satisfaction increase, so causal attribution to the script requires controlling for concurrent events.

scenario: A restaurant wants to estimate whether offering live music nights (X) increases revenue (Y). The owner says: “If we only analyze nights when the restaurant is busy (Z = ‘high foot traffic’), we might create a misleading relationship because busyness is influenced by both music and other factors.”
claim: Conditioning on a ‘busy night’ indicator can introduce bias when estimating the effect of live music on revenue.

Z.name: High foot traffic / busyness

trap.subtype_name: Busyness is affected by multiple causes

causal_structure: X → Z ← U and U → Y (conditioning on Z opens bias via U)
key_insight: Selecting/conditioning on a variable affected by both the intervention and other causes can distort causal comparisons.

hidden_timestamp.question: Is busyness affected both by live music and other drivers (weather, holidays) that also affect revenue?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—plausible and common.

wise_refusal: Estimate effects by comparing comparable nights without conditioning on post-treatment busyness; consider matched nights or randomized scheduling.
label: YES

hidden_structure.notes: Z is downstream of X and U; conditioning opens bias.

gold_rationale: The owner’s caution is correct: ‘busy night’ is a potential collider influenced by X and other factors. Conditioning on it can introduce spurious associations and bias the estimated effect of music on revenue.

scenario: Lena missed the bus because she left home 10 minutes later than usual. She says: “If I had left at my usual time, I would have caught the bus.”
claim: If Lena had left at her usual time, she would have caught the bus.

X.name: Leaving home at the usual earlier time

Z.name: Bus schedule / departure time that morning

trap.subtype_name: Shared cause affects both action and outcome across worlds

causal_structure: X → Y given Z (schedule fixed; earlier departure increases catching probability)
key_insight: If the schedule was fixed and the only change is leaving earlier, the counterfactual is well-defined and often valid.

hidden_timestamp.question: Was the bus on its normal schedule (not unusually early) and was leaving earlier sufficient to arrive before departure?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes by setup (left 10 minutes late caused miss; usual time would restore the buffer).
