wise_refusal: Use precise timelines and a control corridor (diff-in-diff) to separate bike-lane effects from other concurrent infrastructure changes.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Even if X could affect Y, a drop that begins before X points to Z (or other prior changes) as the driver of that observed drop.

gold_rationale: If the commute-time drop started before the bike lane opened, the lane cannot explain that initial improvement; the official claim confuses temporal order.

scenario: A manager wants to improve ‘productivity’ and starts rewarding employees based on number of emails sent per day (Y). After the policy (X), email counts rise and the manager concludes: “Productivity increased.”
claim: Because email counts rose after the incentive policy, true productivity increased.

Y.name: Number of emails sent per day (proxy metric)

Z.name: True productivity / valuable work output (the real target)

trap.subtype_name: Proxy metric diverges from the true target

causal_structure: X → Y and Z → Y (emails can rise from incentives even if Z is unchanged)
key_insight: A proxy metric can be directly moved by incentives without improving the underlying target.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do more emails correspond to more completed high-quality work, or can email volume be inflated without real output?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Email volume can be inflated without improving output.

wise_refusal: Measure productivity with closer-to-target outcomes (deliverables, quality, cycle time). Avoid treating an easily gamed proxy as the target.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Y is influenced by incentives X and is only imperfectly related to Z; inferring Z increased from Y increasing is invalid.

gold_rationale: Email counts are a proxy that can increase due to incentives without any improvement in true productivity.

scenario: A school adopts a new reading program (X) and tracks ‘minutes logged on the reading app’ (Y) as evidence of improved literacy. App minutes increase, and administrators conclude: “Students are reading better now.”
claim: An increase in app minutes after adopting the program means literacy improved.

Z.name: Actual reading comprehension / literacy (the real target)

trap.subtype_name: Engagement proxy may not track learning

causal_structure: X → Y and Z → Y (minutes can rise due to requirements/compliance without Z improving)
key_insight: Engagement metrics can be pushed up without changing the underlying skill you care about.

hidden_timestamp.question: Can minutes be inflated (keeping the app open, auto-play) without real reading or comprehension gains?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—minutes are easy to game.

wise_refusal: Use direct literacy outcomes (comprehension tests, reading assessments) and audit whether app time reflects actual reading, not just logged minutes.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Y can increase due to policy/compliance even if Z is unchanged; proxy–target gap.

gold_rationale: Logged app minutes are a proxy and can rise without improving comprehension; concluding literacy improved from minutes alone is not justified.

scenario: A restaurant starts offering a small discount to customers who leave a review (X). After the change, the average star rating (Y) rises. The owner concludes: “The food quality improved.”
claim: The discount policy caused food quality to improve because star ratings increased after the policy.

X.name: Offering a discount for leaving a review

Z.name: Who leaves reviews and how they respond under incentives (reviewer mix/behavior)

trap.subtype_name: Policy changes who reports and what gets reported

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (incentives change reviewer pool/behavior; ratings can change without quality change)
key_insight: Changing incentives can change the measurement/reporting process, contaminating the metric.

hidden_timestamp.question: Did the discount change who leaves reviews (composition) or how they rate, rather than changing food quality?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Very plausible.

wise_refusal: Use additional outcome measures (repeat-customer rates, complaints, blind tastings) to assess food quality; incentivized ratings can be distorted.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Incentives alter reporting behavior and the reviewer population; ratings are not a clean measure of quality.

gold_rationale: Ratings can rise because incentives changed who reviews and how they rate; this does not imply food quality improved.

scenario: A fitness app introduces a ‘daily streak’ badge (X) and sends more push notifications to keep streaks alive. After rollout, users’ reported workouts (Y) increase. The app team concludes: “The badge increased real exercise.”
claim: The badge feature caused users to exercise more because reported workouts increased after rollout.

Z.name: User logging/recording behavior (compliance/gaming) vs actual exercise

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (streak incentives increase logging; Y may rise without true behavior change)
key_insight: When rewards depend on reporting, people may adapt by logging more rather than changing the underlying behavior.

hidden_timestamp.question: Can users keep a streak via low-effort or easily logged activity (or manual entries) without meaningful exercise?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—many apps allow easy logging and low thresholds.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if ‘reported workouts’ are tightly verified by objective sensors and cannot be gamed
conditional_answers.answer: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN
conditional_answers.rationale: Then increases are more credible, though other concurrent changes and seasonality still matter.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if logging can be easily gamed or reminders mainly increase reporting
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: The metric can rise via feedback on reporting rather than real exercise.

wise_refusal: Validate with objective measures (wearables, heart rate, step counts) and run A/B tests. Separate logging compliance from true exercise outcomes.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: The intervention can primarily affect logging behavior, contaminating the reported outcome.

gold_rationale: Reported workouts can increase because incentives and reminders change logging behavior; without objective measures, the causal claim about real exercise is conditional.

scenario: People who buy organic groceries (X) in a neighborhood tend to have lower rates of obesity (Y). A blogger claims: “Buying organic causes people to be healthier.”
claim: Buying organic groceries causes lower obesity rates.

Z.name: Socioeconomic status and health-oriented lifestyle (diet, exercise, healthcare access)

trap.subtype_name: A common cause drives both purchase and health

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (lifestyle/SES confounds the association)
key_insight: An observed association can be explained by a third factor that affects both behavior and outcomes.

hidden_timestamp.question: Do higher-SES or more health-conscious people both buy organic and engage in other healthy behaviors?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—very plausible.

wise_refusal: Control for SES, baseline health, diet patterns, and exercise, or use quasi-experiments (price shocks/subsidies) before claiming causation.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Omitted Z explains the association; X may not causally affect Y.

gold_rationale: Organic purchasing is correlated with SES and health-conscious lifestyles that also affect obesity; without addressing Z, the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: Students who attend after-school enrichment clubs (X) tend to have higher grades (Y). A parent concludes: “The clubs cause higher grades.”
claim: After-school enrichment clubs cause students to earn higher grades.

Z.name: Parental support/resources and student motivation

trap.subtype_name: Support/resources drive both participation and grades

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (support and motivation confound participation and grades)
key_insight: Self-selection into beneficial activities often reflects prior advantages that also drive outcomes.

hidden_timestamp.question: Are students who attend clubs also more motivated or supported at home in ways that affect grades?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Yes—very plausible.

wise_refusal: Compare similar students (matched on prior grades/support) or use lotteries/assignment into oversubscribed clubs to estimate causal effects.
label: NO

hidden_structure.notes: Omitted Z can explain both participation and higher grades.

gold_rationale: Without controlling for parental support and motivation (Z) or using random assignment, the causal claim is not established.

scenario: A budgeting app reports that users who enabled ‘automatic savings’ (X) saved more money over three months (Y). The company claims: “Turning on auto-savings causes people to save more.”
claim: Enabling auto-savings causes users to save more money.

Z.name: Pre-existing motivation/financial stability that influences opting in and saving

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (opt-in comparisons confound feature effect with user type)
key_insight: Opt-in features often attract users already inclined to the desired behavior, inflating estimated effects.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were opt-in users already saving more (or more financially stable) before enabling auto-savings?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely; opt-in behavior correlates with motivation and stability.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if enabling auto-savings was randomized (or assigned by lottery/encouragement) among comparable users
conditional_answers.answer: YES/PARTIAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Randomization reduces selection bias and supports a causal interpretation.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if enabling is purely opt-in and motivated savers disproportionately enable it
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: The association can be explained by self-selection.

wise_refusal: Don’t infer causality from opt-in comparisons. Use randomized encouragement, staggered rollouts, or matching on pre-treatment saving behavior.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Selection into X is driven by Z; without a design fix, the causal effect of X on Y is not identified.

gold_rationale: Auto-savings is opt-in; differences may reflect who chooses the feature rather than the feature causing increased saving.

scenario: A company offers an optional leadership workshop (X). Six months later, workshop attendees have higher promotion rates (Y). HR concludes: “The workshop increases promotions.”
claim: Attending the optional leadership workshop causes higher promotion rates.

Z.name: Pre-existing high potential / manager nomination / motivation

trap.subtype_name: High-potential employees are more likely to attend

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (promotion differences can reflect selection into the workshop)
key_insight: Optional programs often attract people already on a promotion track, making simple comparisons misleading.

hidden_timestamp.question: Were attendees disproportionately identified as high potential before the workshop?
hidden_timestamp.answer: Likely; optional leadership programs often target/attract high-potential employees.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if attendance was randomized among eligible employees (or assigned via lottery due to limited seats)
conditional_answers.answer: YES/PARTIAL
conditional_answers.rationale: Randomization reduces selection bias and supports a causal estimate.

conditional_answers.condition: Answer if high-potential employees disproportionately attend (self-selection or nomination)
conditional_answers.answer: NO
conditional_answers.rationale: Promotion differences can be explained by pre-existing potential rather than the workshop.

wise_refusal: Use random assignment (lottery) when seats are limited, or compare matched employees based on prior performance/manager ratings.
label: CONDITIONAL

hidden_structure.notes: Selection into X is driven by Z; without randomization or strong controls, the causal effect is not identified.

gold_rationale: Because the workshop is optional, attendance is confounded by motivation/high-potential selection, which also predicts promotion.
